{"uri": "8184572670", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "03:20:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T03:20:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T03:18:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9490196108818054, "url": "https://www.deccanherald.com/world/president-biden-to-do-what-is-best-for-americans-white-house-on-tibet-policy-bill-3072079", "title": "President Biden to do what is best for Americans: White House on Tibet policy bill", "body": "The Resolve Tibet Act is a bipartisan bill to enhance US support for Tibet and promote dialogue between the People's Republic of China and the Dalai Lama toward a peaceful resolution of the long-standing dispute between Tibet and China.\n\nThe Act enhances US support for Tibet - empowering State Department officials to actively and directly counter disinformation about Tibet from the Chinese government, reject false claims that Tibet has been part of China since \"ancient times\", push for negotiations without preconditions between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama or his representatives or the democratically elected leaders of the Tibetan community, and affirm the State Department's responsibility to coordinate with other governments in multilateral efforts toward the goal of a negotiated agreement on Tibet.\n\nChina is opposed to the Act and has asked Biden not to sign it.\n\n\"Anyone or any force who attempts to destabilise Xizang to contain or suppress China will not succeed,\" Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Lin Jian told reporters in Beijing on Tuesday. \"The US should not sign the bill. China will take resolute measures to defend its sovereignty, security and development interests,\" he said.\n\nChina officially refers to Tibet as Xizang.\n\nChina in April this year said it would talk only with the representatives of the Dalai Lama and not the officials of the Tibetan government in exile based in India.\n\nAt the same time, China ruled out dialogue on the Dalai Lama's long-pending demand for autonomy for his remote Himalayan homeland.\n\nIn its talks with China between 2002 and 2010, the Tibetan side pitched genuine autonomy for the Tibetan people in line with the middle-way policy as proposed by the Dalai Lama.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has said he does not seek political independence for Tibet but seeks autonomy for all Tibetan areas which include Gansu, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan provinces besides the current official Tibet Autonomous Region, a truncated version of Tibet before it was annexed by China.\n\nAfter a failed anti-Chinese uprising in 1959, the 14th Dalai Lama fled Tibet and came to India where he set up the government-in-exile.\n\nRelations between the two sides strained further due to protests against China in Tibetan areas in {"uri": "8184481359", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "01:19:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T01:19:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T01:18:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9450980424880981, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/president-biden-to-do-what-is-best-for-americans-white-house-on-tibet-policy-bill-4768339", "title": "President Biden to do what is best for Americans: White House on Tibet policy bill", "body": "Washington, Jun 19 (PTI) US President Joe Biden is going to take a decision that he thinks is in the best interest of the United States, the White House has said, after China warned of \"resolute measures\" if the Tibet policy bill is signed into law.\n\nThe US Congress passed this month a legislation, the Resolve Tibet Act, calling for a peaceful resolution of the dispute over the status and governance of Tibet. It also calls on Beijing to resume dialogue with the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama.\n\n\"The President is going to do what he thinks is best on behalf of the American people, that's what I can tell you,\" White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters at her daily news conference on Tuesday when asked about China's warning.\n\nThe Resolve Tibet Act is a bipartisan bill to enhance US support for Tibet and promote dialogue between the People's Republic of China and the Dalai Lama toward a peaceful resolution of the long-standing dispute between Tibet and China.\n\nThe Act enhances US support for Tibet - empowering State Department officials to actively and directly counter disinformation about Tibet from the Chinese government, reject false claims that Tibet has been part of China since \"ancient times\", push for negotiations without preconditions between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama or his representatives or the democratically elected leaders of the Tibetan community, and affirm the State Department's responsibility to coordinate with other governments in multilateral efforts toward the goal of a negotiated agreement on Tibet.\n\nChina is opposed to the Act and has asked Biden not to sign it.\n\n\"Anyone or any force who attempts to destabilise Xizang to contain or suppress China will not succeed,\" Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Lin Jian told reporters in Beijing on Tuesday. \"The US should not sign the bill. China will take resolute measures to defend its sovereignty, security and development interests,\" he said.\n\nChina officially refers to Tibet as Xizang.\n\nChina in April this year said it would talk only with the representatives of the Dalai Lama and not the officials of the Tibetan government in exile based in India.\n\nAt the same time, China ruled out dialogue on the Dalai Lama's long-pending demand for autonomy for his remote Himalayan homeland.\n\nIn its talks with China between 2002 and 2010, the Tibetan side pitched genuine autonomy for the Tibetan people in line with the middle-way policy as proposed by the Dalai Lama.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has said he does not seek political independence for Tibet but seeks autonomy for all Tibetan areas which include Gansu, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan provinces besides the current official Tibet Autonomous Region, a truncated version of Tibet before it was annexed by China.\n\nAfter a failed anti-Chinese uprising in 1959, the 14th Dalai Lama fled Tibet and came to India where he set up the government-in-exile.\n\nRelations between the two sides strained further due to protests against China in Tibetan areas in 2008. It also calls on Beijing to resume dialogue with the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama.\n\nAlso Read | Same-Sex Marriage in Thailand: Senate Passes Landmark Bill, To Become First Country in Southeast Asia To Recognise LGBTQ Marriages.\n\n\"The President is going to do what he thinks is best on behalf of the American people, that's what I can tell you,\" White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters at her daily news conference on Tuesday when asked about China's warning.\n\nThe Resolve Tibet Act is a bipartisan bill to enhance US support for Tibet and promote dialogue between the People's Republic of China and the Dalai Lama toward a peaceful resolution of the long-standing dispute between Tibet and China.\n\nAlso Read | Juneteenth 2024 Travel Guide: From Texas to New York City, 7 Places To Visit To Celebrate and Experience the True Spirit of the US Federal Holiday.\n\nThe Act enhances US support for Tibet - empowering State Department officials to actively and directly counter disinformation about Tibet from the Chinese government, reject false claims that Tibet has been part of China since \"ancient times\", push for negotiations without preconditions between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama or his representatives or the democratically elected leaders of the Tibetan community, and affirm the State Department's responsibility to coordinate with other governments in multilateral efforts toward the goal of a negotiated agreement on Tibet.\n\nChina is opposed to the Act and has asked Biden not to sign it.\n\n\"Anyone or any force who attempts to destabilise Xizang to contain or suppress China will not succeed,\" Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Lin Jian told reporters in Beijing on Tuesday. \"The US should not sign the bill. China will take resolute measures to defend its sovereignty, security and development interests,\" he said.\n\nChina officially refers to Tibet as Xizang.\n\nChina in April this year said it would talk only with the representatives of the Dalai Lama and not the officials of the Tibetan government in exile based in India.\n\nAt the same time, China ruled out dialogue on the Dalai Lama's long-pending demand for autonomy for his remote Himalayan homeland.\n\nIn its talks with China between 2002 and 2010, the Tibetan side pitched genuine autonomy for the Tibetan people in line with the middle-way policy as proposed by the Dalai Lama.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has said he does not seek political independence for Tibet but seeks autonomy for all Tibetan areas which include Gansu, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan provinces besides the current official Tibet Autonomous Region, a truncated version of Tibet before it was annexed by China.\n\nAfter a failed anti-Chinese uprising in 1959, the 14th Dalai Lama fled Tibet and came to India where he set up the government-in-exile.\n\nRelations between the two sides strained further due to protests against China in Tibetan areas in But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything,' she said.\n\nPelosi admitted the Nobel Peace Prize laureate would not have approved of her comments criticizing China's communist leader.\n\n'When I criticize the Chinese government, he says, let's pray for Nancy to rid her of her negative attitudes,' she added.\n\nPelosi was part of a bipartisan congressional delegation that visited the hillside town the Dalai Lama has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959.\n\nThere, the group which included top Republican Rep. Michael McCaul met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize the administration and hasn\u00b4t held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven U.S. lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the U.S. Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing.\n\nThe bill should now be sent to the White House for President Joe Biden to sign into a law.\n\nPelosi said the bill is 'a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,' eliciting applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said it reaffirmed American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. 'Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,' he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House 'must not sign the bill into law,' or China will take 'resolute measures,' without elaborating on what they may be.\n\n'Its known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,' Lin added, urging the U.S. side to 'have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.'\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet\u00b4s native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, including American presidents - from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama - except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the U.S. on Thursday for medical treatment for his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the U.S. not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nWhile India considers Tibet to be part of China, it hosts Tibetan exiles.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Internewscast Journal"}, {"uri": "8184750595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:16:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:16:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:13:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13545659/US-lawmakers-meet-Dalai-Lama-Indias-Dharamshala-sparking-anger-China.html", "title": "US lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama in India's Dharamshala, sparking...", "body": "DHARAMSHALA, India (AP) - A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama on Wednesday at his residence in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China which views the exiled leader as dangerous separatist.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived a day before in the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. India considers Tibet to be part of China, though it hosts Tibetan exiles.\n\nThe meeting with the spiritual leader is expected to focus on the Resolve Tibet Act, recently passed by the U.S. Congress, aimed at encouraging dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials that could result in a peaceful resolution to the dispute between Tibet and Beijing. The bill will now go to the White House for President Joe Biden's endorsement.\n\nThe visit comes as the U.S. and China have increased talks in recent months, in a bid to normalize strained ties. But news of the visit and the subject of the bill triggered swift backlash from China.\n\nAfter arrival Tuesday, the U.S. delegation met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nHundreds of people on Wednesday gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, where the meeting took place, waving American and Tibetan flags in support.\n\nFILE- Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama greets a guest as he leaves after attending a special event during which exile Tibetans made him traditional offerings and prayed for his long life, at the Tsuglakhang temple in Dharamshala, India, June 11, 2024. A bipartisan U.S. congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama at his residence in India's Dharamshala on Wednesday, in a visit that China has criticized as it views the exiled leader as dangerous separatist. (AP Photo/Ashwini Bhatia, File)\n\nChina doesn\u00b4t recognize the Tibetan government-in-exile and hasn\u00b4t held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Tuesday, McCaul highlighted the importance of the bill, which he said demonstrates that \"the United States of America stands with the people of Tibet.\"\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington to not support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or Beijing will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these measures may be.\n\n\"It\u00b4s known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added on Tuesday, urging the U.S. side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet\u00b4s native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, he has met with all recent American presidents - from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama - except for Donald Trump and he is yet to meet Biden.\n\nBeijing, meanwhile, has repeatedly asked the U.S. not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the U.S. on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nAP writers Krutika Pathi in New Delhi and Didi Tang in Washington contributed Relations deteriorated even more following the COVID-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and in the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959.\n\nAlso read | China urges Biden not to sign Tibet Bill; expresses concern over US Congressional delegation visit to meet Dalai Lama\n\nThere, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet. Beijing doesn't recognize the exiled administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven US lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags. They told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing.\n\nThe bill should now be sent to the White House to be signed into law by President Joe Biden. The bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Pelosi said, eliciting applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said the bill reaffirms American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. \"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing. Lin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or China will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these measures may be. \"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the US side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nAlso read | US Congress team to visit India to boost ties, meet Dalai Lama\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture. The Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with US officials, including meeting American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump.\n\nHe has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.The Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule. {"uri": "8185128323", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:38:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:38:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:35:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2751165/", "title": "Nancy Pelosi's scathing attack on Xi Jinping: 'The legacy of the Dalai Lama will live forever, you will be gone' - ExBulletin", "body": "Former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, on a two-day visit to India, on Wednesday launched a scathing attack on Chinese President Xi Jinping, saying the Dalai Lama's legacy would live forever but that Xi would disappear in a few years. \"His Holiness the Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live long and his legacy will live forever. But you, the President of China, will be gone and no one will give you credit for anything,\" she said during the public felicitation program at Tsuglagkhang complex in Dharamshala.\n\nChina considers the Dalai Lama's spiritual leader a separatist because of his demand for autonomy for Tibet, occupied by Beijing in the 1950s.\n\nDuring her speech, Pelosi said the Dalai Lama would not approve of her comments against China. \"When I criticize the Chinese government,\" he (the Dalai Lama) said, \"let's pray that Nancy rids her of her negative attitudes. I hope that he will allow me today to say that change is on the way. As our colleagues have said, hope brings a certain faith and the faith of the Tibetan people in the goodness of others is what will make all the difference.\n\nA US Congress delegation, led by House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaulis, is visiting India to strengthen bilateral ties and meet Tibetan spiritual leader. Former Speaker of the US House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi is part of the delegation that arrived in Dharamsala on Tuesday.\n\nDharamsala has been the seat of power of the Tibetan government in exile since the Dalai Lama arrived in India sixty years ago. Last Wednesday, the U.S. House of Representatives voted 391-26 to approve the Tibet-China Dispute Promotion and Resolution Act, which the Senate passed. The bill would allocate funds to combat what it calls Beijing's \"misinformation\" about Tibet's history, people and institutions.\n\nChina on Tuesday urged US President Joe Biden not to sign the Tibet policy bill. \"The 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the guise of religion,\" Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian said. He also said Beijing was gravely concerned and urged the US side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Lama group and honor the commitments the US has made to China on Xizang-related issues. , a Chinese name for Tibet. Jian also urged the United States to have no contact with the Dalai Lama group in any form.\n\nOn Wednesday, the White House said Biden was going to make a decision he believed was in the best interests of the United States. \"The president is going to do what he thinks is best on behalf of the American people, that's what I can tell you,\" White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters when asked about China's warning.\n\nReferring to the legislation, Pelosi said the passage of this bill (Resolve Tibet Act) is a message to the Chinese government that the United States has clear thinking and understanding on this issue of Tibet's freedom. \"The listening to the head of our delegation and the head of the Foreign Affairs Committee was masterful not only in terms of the policy, but also in the process of getting it passed in the most bipartisan way.\"\n\nThe Resolve Tibet Act is a bipartisan bill aimed at strengthening U.S. support for Tibet and promoting dialogue between the People's Republic of China and the Dalai Lama toward a peaceful resolution of the long-standing dispute between Tibet and China. China. The law strengthens U.S. support for Tibet, empowering State Department officials to actively and directly counter Chinese government misinformation about Tibet and reject false claims that Tibet has been part of China since \" ancient times.\"\n\nThe bill also encourages officials to promote negotiations without preconditions between Beijing and the Dalai Lama or his representatives and to coordinate with other governments in multilateral efforts to reach a negotiated agreement on Tibet.\n\nHowever, Beijing opposes the law and has asked Biden not to sign it. China's Foreign Ministry spokesperson said anyone or any force attempting to destabilize Xizang to contain or suppress China would not succeed. \"The United States should not sign the bill. China will take resolute measures to defend its sovereignty, security and development interests,\" Jian said.\n\nChina, which officially refers to Tibet as Xizang, said earlier this year that it would only talk with representatives of the Dalai Lama and not officials of the Tibetan government in exile. At the same time, China has ruled out any dialogue on the Dalai Lamas' long-standing demand for autonomy for their distant Himalayan homeland.\n\nDuring its negotiations with China between 2002 and 2010, the Tibetan side proposed true autonomy for the Tibetan people, in accordance with the middle ground policy proposed by the Dalai Lama. The Tibetan spiritual leader said he did not seek political independence for Tibet but sought autonomy for all Tibetan regions which include the provinces of Gansu, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan, in addition to the current official autonomous region of Tibet, a truncated version of Tibet before its annexation by China. .\n\nAfter the failure of the anti-Chinese uprising in 1959, the 14th Dalai Lama fled Tibet and came to India. {"uri": "8184627094", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:17:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:17:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:16:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/world/asia/ex-house-speaker-pelosi-other-us-delegation-members-arrive-at-dalai-lama-temple-to-meet-tibetan-spiritual-leader20240619094537/", "title": "Ex-House Speaker Pelosi, other US delegation members arrive at Dalai Lama Temple to meet Tibetan spiritual leader", "body": "Dharamshala [Himachal Pradesh], June 19 (ANI): Former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other members of the Congressional delegation arrived at the Dalai Lama Temple on Wednesday to meet with the Tibetan spiritual leader.\n\nDisciples of the Dalai Lama were also seen in the temple complex this morning.\n\nThe bipartisan delegation from the US headed by Republican Chair of the US House Foreign Affairs Committee, Michael McCaul was received by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at Himachal Pradesh's Kangra Airport on Tuesday.\n\nAhead of the meeting of the American delegation with the Dalai Lama, Deputy Speaker of Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, Dolma Tsering Teykhang said that the visit of the US lawmakers show \"Tibet is not alone.\"\n\n\"They are here to experience a different way of culture that Tibetans have...we are going to have the official get-together in the meeting...It sends (the message) that Tibet is not alone. United States is with Tibet and human rights still matter. This is a message not only for Tibet but anybody who is aspiring for human rights and for freedom...\" Dolma Tsering Teykhang told ANI.\n\n\"All those who are suffering under the intimidation of China and the expansionist mentality of Xi Jinping, I think this is a very big message for them...\" the Deputy Speaker of Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile said.\n\nDecrying China's authoritarian approach, she said that Beijing is \"annoyed\" with anyone who supports Tibet.\n\n\"China is annoyed with anything who supports Tibet. We are here not to annoy or humiliate China...representatives and senators are here to support just the cause. So, when there is truth, you have a supporter and if there is any truth or when they rectify the wrong politics they are practicing in Tibet, they will also get a lot of support...\" she said.\n\nEarlier this week, the US Congress passed a bill urging Beijing to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nThe US House of Representatives passed the bill 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', also known as the 'Resolve Tibet Act', and it now heads to President Joe Biden for a signature to become law, Radio Free Asia reported.\n\nThe legislation rejects Beijing's stance that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and urges China to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama.\"\n\nIt also urged China to begin talks with the Dalai Lama, who is the spiritual leader of Tibet, and other Tibetan leaders about how Tibet is governed. No formal talks between two sides have taken place since 2010.\n\nUpon her arrival in Dharamshala, former US House Speaker Pelosi said \"It's very exciting to be here.\" Incidentally, Pelosi had in the year 2022 visited Taiwan which resulted in ties between US and China entering a frosty phase.\n\nMcCaul affirmed President Joe Biden's intention to sign the 'Resolve Tibet Act', which was passed last week by Congress. The Resolve Tibet Act urges Beijing to re-engage with Tibetan leaders for a peaceful resolution of their governance dispute with China.\n\nThe US Representative expressed enthusiasm about the upcoming meeting with the Dalai Lama, emphasizing the significance of the bill passed by Congress.\n\nMeanwhile, China said on Tuesday that Beijing is \"gravely concerned\" over the visit of the US delegation to Dharamshala.\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian addressing a regular press conference yesterday asked the US to fully recognise the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Group and to \"stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" the Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson said.\n\n\"We are gravely concerned over the relevant reports and urge the US side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honour the commitments the US has made to China on issues related to Xizang, have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world,\" the Chinese Foreign Ministry said. China calls Tibet by the name Xizang.\n\nThe visiting US delegation visited the Tibetan Parliament in exile and the Tibet Museum Library of Tibetan Works and Archives in Gangchen Kyisjong in Dharamshala on Tuesday. {"uri": "2024-06-394260158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:08:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:08:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:50:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.wboc.com/news/international/us-lawmakers-meet-with-dalai-lama-in-indias-dharamshala-sparking-anger-from-china/article_aace90dc-3282-5994-a036-46138ffe8860.html", "title": "US lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China", "body": "A bipartisan U.S. congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama at his residence in India's Dharamshala on Wednesday, in a visit that China has criticized as it views the exiled leader as dangerous separatist\n\nDHARAMSHALA, India (AP) -- A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama on Wednesday at his residence in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China which views the exiled leader as dangerous separatist.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived a day before in the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. India considers Tibet to be part of China, though it hosts Tibetan exiles.\n\nThe meeting with the spiritual leader is expected to focus on the Resolve Tibet Act, recently passed by the U.S. Congress, aimed at encouraging dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials that could result in a peaceful resolution to the dispute between Tibet and Beijing. The bill will now go to the White House for President Joe Biden's endorsement.\n\nThe visit comes as the U.S. and China have increased talks in recent months, in a bid to normalize strained ties. But news of the visit and the subject of the bill triggered swift backlash from China.\n\nAfter arrival Tuesday, the U.S. delegation met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nHundreds of people on Wednesday gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, where the meeting took place, waving American and Tibetan flags in support.\n\nChina doesn't recognize the Tibetan government-in-exile and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Tuesday, McCaul highlighted the importance of the bill, which he said demonstrates that \"the United States of America stands with the people of Tibet.\"\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington to not support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or Beijing will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these measures may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added on Tuesday, urging the U.S. side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, he has met with all recent American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump and he is yet to meet Biden.\n\nBeijing, meanwhile, has repeatedly asked the U.S. not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the U.S. on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nAP writers Krutika Pathi in New Delhi and Didi Tang in Washington contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": "wboc.com", {"uri": "8185074136", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:05:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:05:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:02:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13546367/US-delegation-meets-Dalai-Lama-India--sparking-anger-China.html", "title": "US delegation meets Dalai Lama in India - sparking anger from China", "body": "A bipartisan US congressional delegation has met the Dalai Lama at his residence in India's Dharamshala.\n\nThe move sparked anger from China, which views the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism as a dangerous separatist.\n\nThe visit came after Washington and Beijing restarted talks after several years of turmoil that began after the imposition of tariffs on Chinese goods under the Trump administration.\n\nRelations deteriorated even more following the Covid-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and in the Taiwan Strait.\n\nRepublican representative Michael McCaul was greeted by the Dalai Lama in Dharamshala, India (Office of the Dalai Lama via AP)\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican representative Michael McCaul and including Democratic former house speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959.\n\nThere, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing does not recognise the exiled administration and has not held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven US members of congress addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing.\n\nThe bill should now be sent to the White House to be signed into law by President Joe Biden.\n\nThe bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet\", Ms Pelosi said, eliciting applause.\n\nAn exiled Tibetan was among those celebrating the event (AP)\n\nMr McCaul, the Republican representative, said the bill reaffirms American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination.\n\n\"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said, as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill triggered a swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law\", or China will take \"resolute measures\".\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Mr Lin added, urging the American side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world\".\n\nDemocratic former House speaker Nancy Pelosi addressed the public after the meeting (AP)\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection for Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with US officials, including meeting American presidents - from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama - except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Mr Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while he is there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nWhile India considers Tibet to be part of China, it hosts Tibetan exiles.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": {"uri": "2024-06-394265051", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:15:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:15:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:45:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/nation/us-lawmakers-meet-with-dalai-lama-in-indias-dharamshala-sparking-anger-from-china/", "title": "US lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China", "body": "DHARAMSHALA, India (AP) -- A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama on Wednesday at his residence in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China which views the exiled leader as dangerous separatist.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived a day before in the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. India considers Tibet to be part of China, though it hosts Tibetan exiles.\n\nThe meeting with the spiritual leader is expected to focus on the Resolve Tibet Act, recently passed by the U.S. Congress, aimed at encouraging dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials that could result in a peaceful resolution to the dispute between Tibet and Beijing. The bill will now go to the White House for President Joe Biden's endorsement.\n\nThe visit comes as the U.S. and China have increased talks in recent months, in a bid to normalize strained ties. But news of the visit and the subject of the bill triggered swift backlash from China.\n\nAfter arrival Tuesday, the U.S. delegation met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nHundreds of people on Wednesday gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, where the meeting took place, waving American and Tibetan flags in support.\n\nChina doesn't recognize the Tibetan government-in-exile and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Tuesday, McCaul highlighted the importance of the bill, which he said demonstrates that \"the United States of America stands with the people of Tibet.\"\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington to not support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or Beijing will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these measures may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added on Tuesday, urging the U.S. side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, he has met with all recent American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump and he is yet to meet Biden.\n\nBeijing, meanwhile, has repeatedly asked the U.S. not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the U.S. on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\n___\n\nAP writers Krutika Pathi in New Delhi and Didi Tang in Washington contributed reporting.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8184686359", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "05:20:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T05:20:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:18:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.etvbharat.com/en/!international/what-is-the-tibet-bill-as-us-delegation-in-dharamshala-to-meet-dalai-lama-spotlight-again-on-chinas-control-enn24061901509", "title": "What Is Tibet Bill? As US Delegation Goes To Meet Dalai Lama, Spotlight Again On China's Control", "body": "Dharamshala: As the Resolve Tibet Bill advances closer to becoming law to enhance American support for Tibet, a high-level US congressional delegation, led by Michael McCaul and comprising former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, reached Dalai Lama's Temple at Dharamshala in Himachal Pradesh on Wednesday to meet Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, and interact with representatives of Central Tibetan Administration (CTA), also known as the Tibetan government in exile.\n\nCTA believes the significant meeting highlights bipartisan US support for Tibetan autonomy and promotes dialogue between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama's envoys. The Dalai Lama, who fled Tibet in March 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule, believes in a 'middle-way' approach, meaning greater autonomy for Tibet rather than outright independence.\n\nOn Tuesday, Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Lin Jian urged US President Biden to not sign the Resolve Tibet Act into law and accused the Dalai Lama of being an 'anti-China separatist' acting under the cloak of religion.\n\nDalai Lama, the 88-year-old Tibetan monk lives in exile in McLeodganj, a small and quaint hill station in the suburbs of Dharamsala in the northern Indian Himalayas. US lawmakers last week passed a bipartisan bill to enhance support for Tibet and promote dialogue between China and the Dalai Lama towards a peaceful resolution of the long-standing dispute between Tibet and China.\n\nIt now goes to President Joe Biden, who is expected to sign it into law. The visiting lawmakers, including Speaker Emerita Nancy Pelosi, will have an audience with His Holiness the Dalai Lama, on Wednesday morning, a CTA spokesperson said.\n\nCTA officials believe the Resolve Tibet Act, once signed, is a powerful reaffirmation of the United States' steadfast commitment to the people of Tibet. Visiting House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman McCaul is an original sponsor of the bill. Supporting the bill, McCaul had said, \"The United States has never accepted that Tibet was part of China since ancient times as the CCP (Chinese Communist Party) falsely claims. This legislation clarifies US policy and highlights the unique language, religion, and culture of the Tibetan people. It directs US diplomacy to push back against CCP propaganda. In addition, it ensures Tibetans have a say in their own future.\"\n\n\"This bill stresses the need for dialogue between the CCP and other democratically elected leaders of Tibet. Any resolution must include the wishes and voice of the Tibetan people...Passing this bill demonstrates America's resolve that the CCP's status quo in Tibet is not acceptable and I can think of no greater message or gift to the Dalai Lama and the people of Tibet than the swift passage of this bill to get to the President's desk as soon as possible to help put the people of Tibet in charge of their own future,\" he said.\n\nThe US delegation visit comes two days ahead of a planned trip by the Dalai Lama to the US to undergo medical treatment for his knees. However, his office said there will be no public engagement, including public audiences, of His Holiness during the visit.\n\nEn route to the US, the 14th Dalai Lama will briefly halt in Zurich, Switzerland on June 22. As per the schedule, the visiting delegation will be briefed on the evolution, composition, and functioning of the Tibetan Parliament-in-exile.\n\nThe previous crucial meeting of the spiritual leader with the US high-level delegation led by Special Coordinator for Tibetan Issues Under Secretary Uzra Zeya was held here on May 18, 2022. That was the sixth visitation of the successive Special Coordinators to Dharamsala. As per the CTA, in January 2000 Assistant Secretary Julia Taft became the first Special Coordinator to visit Dharamsala. In November 2006, Undersecretary Paula J. Dobriansky visited. In 2009, Undersecretary Maria Otero (then designated to serve as Special Coordinator), accompanied Valerie Jarrett, Senior Advisor to President Barack Obama, on a trip to Dharamsala. Undersecretary Sarah Sewall visited Dharamsala in 2014 and 2016.\n\nChina vs US debate on Tibet\n\nMeanwhile, US President Joe Biden is going to take a decision that he thinks is in the best interest of the United States, the White House has said, after China warned of \"resolute measures\" if the Tibet policy bill is signed into law.\n\nThe US Congress, which passed this month the legislation, also calls on Beijing to resume dialogue with the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama.\n\n\"The President is going to do what he thinks is best on behalf of the American people, that's what I can tell you,\" White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre told reporters at her daily news conference on Tuesday when asked about China's warning.\n\nThe Act enhances US support for Tibet empowering State Department officials to actively and directly counter disinformation about Tibet from the Chinese government, reject false claims that Tibet has been part of China since \"ancient times\", push for negotiations without preconditions between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama or his representatives or the democratically elected leaders of the Tibetan community, and affirm the State Department's responsibility to coordinate with other governments in multilateral efforts toward the goal of a negotiated agreement on Tibet.\n\nChina officially refers to Tibet as Xizang. China in April this year said it would talk only with the representatives of the Dalai Lama and not the officials of the Tibetan government in exile based in India.\n\nAt the same time, China ruled out dialogue on the Dalai Lama's long-pending demand for autonomy for his remote Himalayan homeland. In its talks with China between 2002 and 2010, the Tibetan side pitched genuine autonomy for the Tibetan people in line with the middle-way policy as proposed by the Dalai Lama.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has said he does not seek political independence for Tibet but seeks autonomy for all Tibetan areas which include Gansu, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan provinces besides the current official Tibet Autonomous Region, a truncated version of Tibet before it was annexed by China. After a failed anti-Chinese uprising in 1959, the 14th Dalai Lama fled Tibet and came to India where he set up the government-in-exile.", "source": {"uri": "etvbharat.com", "dataType": "news", United States is with Tibet and human rights still matter. This is a message not only for Tibet but anybody who is aspiring for human rights and for freedom...\" Dolma Tsering Teykhang told ANI.\n\n\"All those who are suffering under the intimidation of China and the expansionist mentality of Xi Jinping, I think this is a very big message for them...\" the Deputy Speaker of Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile said.\n\nDecrying China's authoritarian approach, she said that Beijing is \"annoyed\" with anyone who supports Tibet.\n\n\"China is annoyed with anything who supports Tibet. We are here not to annoy or humiliate China...representatives and senators are here to support just the cause. So, when there is truth, you have a supporter and if there is any truth or when they rectify the wrong politics they are practicing in Tibet, they will also get a lot of support...\" she said.\n\nEarlier this week, the US Congress passed a bill urging Beijing to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nThe US House of Representatives passed the bill 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', also known as the 'Resolve Tibet Act', and it now heads to President Joe Biden for a signature to become law, Radio Free Asia reported.\n\nThe legislation rejects Beijing's stance that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and urges China to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama.\"\n\nIt also urged China to begin talks with the Dalai Lama, who is the spiritual leader of Tibet, and other Tibetan leaders about how Tibet is governed. No formal talks between two sides have taken place since 2010.\n\nUpon her arrival in Dharamshala, former US House Speaker Pelosi said \"It's very exciting to be here.\" Incidentally, Pelosi had in the year 2022 visited Taiwan which resulted in ties between US and China entering a frosty phase.\n\nMcCaul affirmed President Joe Biden's intention to sign the 'Resolve Tibet Act', which was passed last week by Congress. The Resolve Tibet Act urges Beijing to re-engage with Tibetan leaders for a peaceful resolution of their governance dispute with China.\n\nThe US Representative expressed enthusiasm about the upcoming meeting with the Dalai Lama, emphasizing the significance of the bill passed by Congress.\n\nMeanwhile, China said on Tuesday that Beijing is \"gravely concerned\" over the visit of the US delegation to Dharamshala.\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian addressing a regular press conference yesterday asked the US to fully recognise the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Group and to \"stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" the Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson said.\n\n\"We are gravely concerned over the relevant reports and urge the US side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honour the commitments the US has made to China on issues related to Xizang, have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world,\" the Chinese Foreign Ministry said. China calls Tibet by the name Xizang.\n\nThe visiting US delegation visited the Tibetan Parliament in exile and the Tibet Museum Library of Tibetan Works and Archives in Gangchen Kyisjong in Dharamshala on Tuesday. {"uri": "2024-06-394576228", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:51:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:51:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:01:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jun/19/american-lawmakers-meet-with-dalai-lama-in-indias-/", "title": "U.S. lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China", "body": "DHARAMSHALA, India (AP) -- A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama Wednesday at his residence in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China which views the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism as a dangerous separatist.\n\nThis comes as Washington and Beijing have recently restarted talks after several years of turmoil that began after the imposition of tariffs on Chinese goods under the Trump administration. Relations at the time deteriorated even more following the COVID-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. There, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize said administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven U.S. lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the U.S. Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing. The bill should now be sent to the White House for President Biden to sign into a law.\n\nPelosi said the bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" eliciting applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said it reaffirmed American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. \"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or China will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what they may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the U.S. side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, including American presidents - from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama - except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the U.S. on Thursday for medical treatment for his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the U.S. not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nWhile India considers Tibet to be part of China, it hosts Tibetan exiles.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, Relations deteriorated even more following the COVID-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and in the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. There, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize the exiled administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven US lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing. The bill should now be sent to the White House to be signed into law by President Joe Biden.\n\nThe bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Pelosi said, eliciting applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said the bill reaffirms American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. \"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or China will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these measures may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the US side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with US officials, including meeting American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its {"uri": "8184642046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:34:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:34:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:32:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-ex-house-speaker-pelosi-other-us-delegation-members-arrive-at-dalai-lama-temple-to-meet-tibetan-spiritual-leader-6048152.html", "title": "World News | Ex-House Speaker Pelosi, Other US Delegation Members Arrive at Dalai Lama Temple to Meet Tibetan Spiritual Leader | LatestLY", "body": "Dharamshala [Himachal Pradesh], June 19 (ANI): Former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other members of the Congressional delegation arrived at the Dalai Lama Temple on Wednesday to meet with the Tibetan spiritual leader.\n\nDisciples of the Dalai Lama were also seen in the temple complex this morning.\n\nAlso Read | Apple Sued Over Deleted Messages? Businessman From UK Files Lawsuit Against Apple Over 'Deleted Messages' to Sex Workers Recovered by Wife Leading to Million Pound Divorce.\n\nThe bipartisan delegation from the US headed by Republican Chair of the US House Foreign Affairs Committee, Michael McCaul was received by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at Himachal Pradesh's Kangra Airport on Tuesday.\n\nAhead of the meeting of the American delegation with the Dalai Lama, Deputy Speaker of Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, Dolma Tsering Teykhang said that the visit of the US lawmakers show \"Tibet is not alone.\"\n\nAlso Read | Earthquake in Iran: Four Killed As 5.0-Magnitude Quake Strikes Kashmar County in Razavi Khorasan Province.\n\n\"They are here to experience a different way of culture that Tibetans have...we are going to have the official get-together in the meeting...It sends (the message) that Tibet is not alone. United States is with Tibet and human rights still matter. This is a message not only for Tibet but anybody who is aspiring for human rights and for freedom...\" Dolma Tsering Teykhang told ANI.\n\n\"All those who are suffering under the intimidation of China and the expansionist mentality of Xi Jinping, I think this is a very big message for them...\" the Deputy Speaker of Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile said.\n\nDecrying China's authoritarian approach, she said that Beijing is \"annoyed\" with anyone who supports Tibet.\n\n\"China is annoyed with anything who supports Tibet. We are here not to annoy or humiliate China...representatives and senators are here to support just the cause. So, when there is truth, you have a supporter and if there is any truth or when they rectify the wrong politics they are practicing in Tibet, they will also get a lot of support...\" she said.\n\nEarlier this week, the US Congress passed a bill urging Beijing to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nThe US House of Representatives passed the bill 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', also known as the 'Resolve Tibet Act', and it now heads to President Joe Biden for a signature to become law, Radio Free Asia reported.\n\nThe legislation rejects Beijing's stance that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and urges China to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama.\"\n\nIt also urged China to begin talks with the Dalai Lama, who is the spiritual leader of Tibet, and other Tibetan leaders about how Tibet is governed. No formal talks between two sides have taken place since 2010.\n\nUpon her arrival in Dharamshala, former US House Speaker Pelosi said \"It's very exciting to be here.\" Incidentally, Pelosi had in the year 2022 visited Taiwan which resulted in ties between US and China entering a frosty phase.\n\nMcCaul affirmed President Joe Biden's intention to sign the 'Resolve Tibet Act', which was passed last week by Congress. The Resolve Tibet Act urges Beijing to re-engage with Tibetan leaders for a peaceful resolution of their governance dispute with China.\n\nThe US Representative expressed enthusiasm about the upcoming meeting with the Dalai Lama, emphasizing the significance of the bill passed by Congress.\n\nMeanwhile, China said on Tuesday that Beijing is \"gravely concerned\" over the visit of the US delegation to Dharamshala.Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian addressing a regular press conference yesterday asked the US to fully recognise the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Group and to \"stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" the Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson said.\n\n\"We are gravely concerned over the relevant reports and urge the US side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honour the commitments the US has made to China on issues related to Xizang, have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world,\" the Chinese Foreign Ministry said. China calls Tibet by the name Xizang.\n\nThe visiting US delegation visited the Tibetan Parliament in exile and the Tibet Museum Library of Tibetan Works and Archives in Gangchen Kyisjong in Dharamshala on Tuesday. {"uri": "2024-06-394251815", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:02:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:02:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T01:44:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/us/articles/2024-06-19/us-lawmakers-meet-with-dalai-lama-in-indias-dharamshala-sparking-anger-from-china", "title": "US Lawmakers Meet With Dalai Lama in India's Dharamshala, Sparking Anger From China", "body": "DHARAMSHALA, India (AP) -- A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama on Wednesday at his residence in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China which views the exiled leader as dangerous separatist.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived a day before in the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. India considers Tibet to be part of China, though it hosts Tibetan exiles.\n\nThe meeting with the spiritual leader is expected to focus on the Resolve Tibet Act, recently passed by the U.S. Congress, aimed at encouraging dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials that could result in a peaceful resolution to the dispute between Tibet and Beijing. The bill will now go to the White House for President Joe Biden's endorsement.\n\nThe visit comes as the U.S. and China have increased talks in recent months, in a bid to normalize strained ties. But news of the visit and the subject of the bill triggered swift backlash from China.\n\nAfter arrival Tuesday, the U.S. delegation met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nHundreds of people on Wednesday gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, where the meeting took place, waving American and Tibetan flags in support.\n\nChina doesn't recognize the Tibetan government-in-exile and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Tuesday, McCaul highlighted the importance of the bill, which he said demonstrates that \"the United States of America stands with the people of Tibet.\"\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington to not support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or Beijing will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these measures may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added on Tuesday, urging the U.S. side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, he has met with all recent American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump and he is yet to meet Biden.\n\nBeijing, meanwhile, has repeatedly asked the U.S. not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the U.S. on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\n___\n\nAP writers Krutika Pathi in New Delhi and Didi Tang in Washington contributed reporting.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. This visit upset China, as they see the Buddhist leader, who lives in exile, as someone who promotes separation.\n\nThis comes as Washington and Beijing have recently restarted talks after several years of turmoil that began after the imposition of tariffs on Chinese goods under the Trump administration.\n\nRelations at the time deteriorated even more following the COVID-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959.\n\nThere, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize said administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven US lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing.\n\nThe bill should now be sent to the White House for President Joe Biden to sign into a law.\n\nPelosi said the bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" eliciting applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said it reaffirmed American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination.\n\n\"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or China will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what they may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the US side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with US officials, including American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment for his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth {"uri": "8186670008", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "08:59:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T08:59:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T08:58:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/tibet-talks-nancy-pelosi-meets-dalai-lama-in-india-he-set-to-fly-to-us-13784306.html", "title": "Day after meeting Pelosi in India, Dalai Lama set to fly to US", "body": "The Dalai Lama with former US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other members of the US Congressional delegation at his residence, in Dharamshala. (PTI)\n\nA day after a bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama at his residence in Dharamshala, the Tibetan spiritual leader is set to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment for his knees. It remains unclear if he will meet any US officials during his stay in the country. The visit poses questions about why former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other lawmakers travelled to India to meet with the Dalai Lama, just a day before his scheduled visit to the US.\n\nPelosi after meeting the Tibetan spiritual leader on Wednesday said that the legacy of the Dalai Lama \"will live forever\" and nobody will give Chinese President Xi Jinping any credit.\n\nThe delegation is led by US House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaul and has members including Pelosi, who is now Speaker Emerita, and prominent US Congressional members -- Mariannette Miller, Gregory Meeks, Nicole Malliotakis, Jim McGovern, and Ami Bera.\n\nThe Resolve Tibet Act\n\nThe US Congress passed this month a legislation, the Resolve Tibet Act, calling for a peaceful resolution of the dispute over the status and governance of Tibet. It also calls on Beijing to resume dialogue with the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama.\n\nThe Resolve Tibet Act is a bipartisan bill to enhance US support for Tibet and promote dialogue between the People's Republic of China and the Dalai Lama toward a peaceful resolution of the long-standing dispute between Tibet and China.\n\nUS President Joe Biden is going to take a decision that he thinks is in the best interest of the United States, the White House has said, after China warned of \"resolute measures\" if the Tibet policy bill is signed into law.\n\nThe Act enhances US support for Tibet empowering State Department officials to actively and directly counter disinformation about Tibet from the Chinese government, reject false claims that Tibet has been part of China since \"ancient times\", push for negotiations without preconditions between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama or his representatives or the democratically elected leaders of the Tibetan community, and affirm the State Department's responsibility to coordinate with other governments in multilateral efforts toward the goal of a negotiated agreement on Tibet. China officially refers to Tibet as Xizang.\n\nChina in April this year said it would talk only with the representatives of the Dalai Lama and not the officials of the Tibetan government in exile based in India.\n\nAt the same time, China ruled out dialogue on the Dalai Lama's long-pending demand for autonomy for his remote Himalayan homeland.\n\nIn its talks with China between 2002 and 2010, the Tibetan side pitched genuine autonomy for the Tibetan people in line with the middle-way policy as proposed by the Dalai Lama.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has said he did not seek political independence for Tibet but seeks autonomy for all Tibetan areas which include Gansu, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan provinces besides the current official Tibet Autonomous Region, a truncated version of Tibet before it was annexed by China.\n\nAfter a failed anti-Chinese uprising in 1959, the 14th Dalai Lama fled Tibet and came to India where he set up the government-in-exile.
