But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything,' she said.\n\nPelosi admitted the Nobel Peace Prize laureate would not have approved of her comments criticizing China's communist leader.\n\n'When I criticize the Chinese government, he says, let's pray for Nancy to rid her of her negative attitudes,' she added.\n\nNancy Pelosi met the Dalai Lama at his residence in India on Wednesday morning in a move that infuriated China\n\nPelosi was part of a bipartisan congressional delegation that visited the hillside town the Dalai Lama has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959.\n\nThere, the group which included top Republican Rep. Michael McCaul met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nRead MoreBREAKING NEWS Thousands of cheering North Koreans line the streets as Putin begins state visit\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize the administration and hasn\u00b4t held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven U.S. lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the U.S. Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing.\n\nThe bill should now be sent to the White House for President Joe Biden to sign into a law.\n\nPelosi said the bill is 'a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,' eliciting applause.\n\n'His Holiness Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live a long time and his legacy will live forever. But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything,' she said\n\nThe Democrat former House Speaker, 84, held talks with the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader by and took swipe at Chinese President Xi Jinping\n\nPelosi was part of a bipartisan congressional delegation that visited the hillside town the Dalai Lama has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959\n\nTop Republican Rep. Michael McCaul also met the Nobel Peace Prize laureate, and said the Chinese Communist Party had warned the lawmakers not to visit\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said it reaffirmed American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. 'Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,' he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House 'must not sign the bill into law,' or China will take 'resolute measures,' without elaborating on what they may be.\n\n'Its known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,' Lin added, urging the U.S. side to 'have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.'\n\nPelosi admitted the Nobel Peace Prize laureate would not have approved of her comments criticizing China's communist leader. 'When I criticize the Chinese government, he says, let's pray for Nancy to rid her of her negative attitudes,' she added\n\nTibetans gather outside the Dalai Lama's hillside home in Dharamshala, India, for the visit from U.S. lawmakers\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet\u00b4s native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, including American presidents - from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama - except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the U.S. on Thursday for medical treatment for his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the U.S. not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic {"uri": "2024-06-394576558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:51:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:51:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:19:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.aol.com/pelosi-other-u-lawmakers-meet-081910353.html", "title": "Pelosi and other U.S. lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama, a move likely to anger China", "body": "Pelosi and other U.S. lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama, a move likely to anger China\n\nJennifer Jett and Mithil Aggarwal\n\nJune 19, 2024 at 10:19 AM\n\nA group of U.S. lawmakers met with Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in India on Wednesday, a move likely to anger China.\n\nThe visit came as President Joe Biden appears poised to sign a bill pressuring Beijing to resolve tensions with Tibet and protect the region's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe bipartisan delegation of seven lawmakers, which was led by Rep. Michael McCaul, R-Texas, and also included former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., arrived Tuesday in Dharamshala, a Himalayan town in northern India where the Dalai Lama, 88, has lived in exile since fleeing China in 1959 after a failed Tibetan uprising against Chinese rule.\n\n\"It is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" McCaul said after the meeting, according to Reuters.\n\nMcCaul said Tuesday that Biden would soon sign a bill passed by Congress last week that presses Beijing to resume negotiations with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders that have been frozen since 2010, and to address Tibetan people's concerns about their cultural, religious and linguistic autonomy.\n\n\"This bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, get ready for that,\" Reuters quoted Pelosi, whose 2022 visit to the Beijing-claimed island of Taiwan prompted China to encircle the island with live-fire military drills after she left, as saying Wednesday.\n\nThe lawmakers' meeting with the Dalai Lama is likely to irritate Beijing at a time when the U.S. and China are trying to improve relations. Beijing views the 1989 Nobel Peace laureate as an anti-China \"separatist,\" which he denies, and opposes any contact with him by foreign officials.\n\nThe Chinese Foreign Ministry said Tuesday that affairs related to Tibet were an internal Chinese matter and that China would take \"resolute measures\" to defend its sovereignty, security and development interests.\n\n\"We urge the U.S. side to adhere to its commitments of recognizing Tibet as part of China and not supporting 'Tibet independence,'\" spokesperson Lin Jian said at a regular news briefing in Beijing. \"The U.S. must not sign the bill into law.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama is traveling to the United States this month for medical treatment on his knees, his office earlier announced. It is unclear whether he will meet with any U.S. officials during the trip.\n\nUntil the presidency of Donald Trump, the Dalai Lama had met with every sitting U.S. president since George H.W. Bush. Biden, who criticized Trump during the 2020 campaign over his failure to meet with the Tibetan spiritual leader, has not met with the Dalai Lama since taking office in 2021.\n\nThe lawmakers' meeting with the Dalai Lama \"seeks to compensate for the Biden administration's reluctance to speak up on Tibet,\" said Brahma Chellaney, a professor emeritus of strategic studies at the Center for Policy Research, a think tank in New Delhi.\n\n\"The U.S. and India need to work together, including countering China's disinformation on Tibet and foiling its plan to install a puppet as the next Dalai Lama,\" he told NBC News in an email.\n\nLike the U.S., India recognizes Tibet as part of China, even as it hosts the Tibetan exiles.\n\nMcCaul said Wednesday that the U.S. would not allow China to interfere in the process of naming a successor to the Dalai Lama, who is believed to be a reincarnation of the Buddha, upon his death.\n\nThere is already a dispute over who is the rightful Panchen Lama, the second-most important figure in Tibetan Buddhism, after the Dalai Lama and the officially atheist Chinese government identified two different people as reincarnations in 1995.\n\nActivists say the Dalai Lama's choice, a 6-year-old child, was kidnapped by the Chinese government days after being named and has been forcibly detained ever since.\n\nChina says Tibet has prospered and modernized under Communist Party rule, pointing to the construction of highways, high-speed railways and other infrastructure and the promotion of tourism.\n\nCritics argue that has come at the cost of the erasure of Tibetan culture, language and religion as Beijing \"Sinicizes\" the remote, mountainous region, which it annexed in the 1950s.\n\n\"Such infliction of suffering and oppression on the Tibetan people by the Chinese Communist Party authorities is unparalleled and unprecedented,\" Tenpa Tsering, president of the Tibetan government-in-exile, said last year.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8185660485", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:38:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:38:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:36:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/06/20/world/asia-oceania/us-lawmakers-meet-with-dalai-lama-angering-china/1952257", "title": "US lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama, angering China", "body": "DHARAMSHALA, India -- A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama at his residence in Dharamshala, northern India, on Wednesday, sparking anger from China, which views the exiled leader as a dangerous separatist.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived a day before in the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. India considers Tibet to be part of China, though it hosts Tibetan exiles.\n\nThe meeting with the spiritual leader is expected to focus on the Resolve Tibet Act, recently passed by the US Congress, aimed at encouraging dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials that could result in a peaceful resolution to the dispute between Tibet and Beijing. The bill will now go to the White House for President Joe Biden's endorsement.\n\nWARM WELCOME A United States congressional delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul, meet with Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama (second from left) in the town of Dharamshala, northern India, on June 19, 2024. PHOTO FROM LESLIE SHEDD VIA AP\n\nThe visit comes as the US and China have increased talks in recent months, in a bid to normalize strained ties. But news of the visit and the subject of the bill triggered swift backlash from China.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nAfter arriving on Tuesday, the US delegation met with officials from the Tibetan government in exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nHundreds of people on Wednesday gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, where the meeting took place, waving American and Tibetan flags in support.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nChina doesn't recognize the Tibetan government in exile and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Tuesday, McCaul highlighted the importance of the bill, which he said demonstrates that \"the United States of America stands with the people of Tibet.\"\n\nLin Jian, a spokesman for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, urged Washington to not support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or Beijing will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin said on Tuesday, urging the US to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with US officials. He has met with all recent American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump, and he is yet to meet Biden.\n\nBeijing, meanwhile, has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he would meet any officials while there.\n\nAdvertisement", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Manila {"uri": "2024-06-394408248", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:31:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:31:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:19:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.arabnews.com/node/2533361/world", "title": "US lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama in India's Dharamshala, sparking", "body": "DHARAMSHALA, India: A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama Wednesday at his residence in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China which views the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism as a dangerous separatist.\n\nThis comes as Washington and Beijing have recently restarted talks after several years of turmoil that began after the imposition of tariffs on Chinese goods under the Trump administration. Relations deteriorated even more following the COVID-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and in the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. There, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize the exiled administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven US lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing. The bill should now be sent to the White House to be signed into law by President Joe Biden.\n\nThe bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Pelosi said, eliciting applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said the bill reaffirms American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. \"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or China will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these measures may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the US side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with US officials, including meeting American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nWhile India considers Tibet to be part of China, it hosts Tibetan exiles.", "source": {"uri": "arabnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arab News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The trip comes days after the U.S. Congress passed a bill with bipartisan support that urges China to begin a dialogue with Tibetan leaders to find a solution to the long-running conflict.\n\nMs. Pelosi was quoted by the media as saying: The Dalai Lama will live a long time and his legacy will live forever, but you, the President (Mr. Xi), will be gone and no one will give you credit for anything. .The Dalai Lama will not approve of me saying this... criticizing the Chinese government. But I hope it will allow me today to say that change is on the way. As our colleagues have said, hope brings a certain faith and the faith of the Tibetan people, in the goodness of others, will make all the difference...\n\nMs. Pelosi also reportedly said that bipartisan approval of the Resolve Tibet Act sends a message to China that Washington has clear thinking on this issue.\n\nThis bill says to the Chinese government: Things have changed now, prepare for this, she reportedly said as she applauded Tibetans at an event Wednesday afternoon.\n\nThe Resolve Tibet Act, which will pressure China to resume 14-year-frozen negotiations with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders, now needs only President Joe Biden's signature, according to media reports to become law. Reports from Beijing claim that Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian has urged the US president not to sign the bipartisan Tibet policy bill passed by both the US Senate and by the House of Representatives.\n\nAt a public reception Wednesday after the meeting with the Dalai Lama, Mr. McCaul reportedly said that Chinese officials had sent the delegation a letter warning us not to come to Dharamsala. He said the United States stood with Tibet in what he called its right to self-determination.\n\nAmerica, beautiful, will support Tibet to remain a powerful force as always, the media was quoted as saying.\n\nIt is worth noting that historically the Dalai Lama, considered for centuries the supreme spiritual leader of Tibet, has always been chosen through a procedure rooted in the belief in reincarnation. The current Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, born in 1935 in Tibet and recognized as the 14th Dalai Lama, fled to India as a young man in 1959, following the failure of a revolt in Tibet against domination Chinese.\n\nBased in Dharamsala, Himachal Pradesh, his current health condition is said to be worrying. It is for this reason that the choice of the next Dalai Lama is ultimately seen as a potential flashpoint between Beijing and the current supporters of the Dalai Lamas exiled in India, who had formed the Central Tibetan Administration, commonly known as of Tibetan government in China. exiled based in Dharamsala several decades ago.\n\nAttacking the Dalai Lama, Beijing, which refers to Tibet under the Chinese name Xizang, said on Tuesday: \"Everyone knows that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in separatist activities anti-Chinese. under the guise of religion. We urge the US side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Lama group, honor the commitments the US has made to China on Xizang-related issues, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world... Xizang's business is purely Chinese. internal affairs and no external interference will ever be allowed...China will take resolute measures to firmly defend its sovereignty, security and development {"uri": "2024-06-394431399", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:52:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:52:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T05:44:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/06/19/us-lawmakers-meet-with-dalai-lama-in-indias-dharamshala-sparking-anger-from-china/", "title": "US lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China", "body": "DHARAMSHALA, India (AP) -- A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama Wednesday at his residence in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China which views the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism as a dangerous separatist.\n\nThis comes as Washington and Beijing have recently restarted talks after several years of turmoil that began after the imposition of tariffs on Chinese goods under the Trump administration. Relations deteriorated even more following the COVID-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and in the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. There, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize the exiled administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven U.S. lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the U.S. Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing. The bill should now be sent to the White House to be signed into law by President Joe Biden.\n\nThe bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Pelosi said, eliciting applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said the bill reaffirms American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. \"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or China will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these measures may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the U.S. side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, including meeting American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the U.S. on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the U.S. not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nWhile India considers Tibet to be part of China, it hosts Tibetan exiles.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Didi Tang in Washington contributed to this report. {"uri": "8185675138", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:49:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:49:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:47:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.indiandefensenews.in/2024/06/ex-house-speaker-pelosi-other-us.html", "title": "Ex-House Speaker Pelosi, Other US Delegation Members Arrive At Dalai Lama Temple To Meet Tibetan Spiritual Leader", "body": "Ex-House Speaker Pelosi, Other US Delegation Members Arrive At Dalai Lama Temple To Meet Tibetan Spiritual Leader Wednesday, June 19, 2024 by Indian Defence News\n\nDharamshala: Former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other members of the Congressional delegation arrived at the Dalai Lama Temple on Wednesday to meet with the Tibetan spiritual leader.\n\nDisciples of the Dalai Lama were also seen in the temple complex this morning.\n\nThe bipartisan delegation from the US headed by Republican Chair of the US House Foreign Affairs Committee, Michael McCaul was received by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at Himachal Pradesh's Kangra Airport on Tuesday.\n\nAhead of the meeting of the American delegation with the Dalai Lama, Deputy Speaker of Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, Dolma Tsering Teykhang said that the visit of the US lawmakers show \"Tibet is not alone.\"\n\n\"They are here to experience a different way of culture that Tibetans have...we are going to have the official get-together in the meeting...It sends (the message) that Tibet is not alone. United States is with Tibet and human rights still matter. This is a message not only for Tibet but anybody who is aspiring for human rights and for freedom...\" Dolma Tsering Teykhang told ANI.\n\n\"All those who are suffering under the intimidation of China and the expansionist mentality of Xi Jinping, I think this is a very big message for them...\" the Deputy Speaker of Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile said.\n\nDecrying China's authoritarian approach, she said that Beijing is \"annoyed\" with anyone who supports Tibet.\n\n\"China is annoyed with anything who supports Tibet. We are here not to annoy or humiliate China...representatives and senators are here to support just the cause. So, when there is truth, you have a supporter and if there is any truth or when they rectify the wrong politics they are practicing in Tibet, they will also get a lot of support...\" she said.\n\nEarlier this week, the US Congress passed a bill urging Beijing to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nThe US House of Representatives passed the bill 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', also known as the 'Resolve Tibet Act', and it now heads to President Joe Biden for a signature to become law, Radio Free Asia reported.\n\nThe legislation rejects Beijing's stance that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and urges China to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama.\"\n\nIt also urged China to begin talks with the Dalai Lama, who is the spiritual leader of Tibet, and other Tibetan leaders about how Tibet is governed. No formal talks between two sides have taken place since 2010.\n\nUpon her arrival in Dharamshala, former US House Speaker Pelosi said \"It's very exciting to be here.\" Incidentally, Pelosi had in the year 2022 visited Taiwan which resulted in ties between US and China entering a frosty phase.\n\nMcCaul affirmed President Joe Biden's intention to sign the 'Resolve Tibet Act', which was passed last week by Congress. The Resolve Tibet Act urges Beijing to re-engage with Tibetan leaders for a peaceful resolution of their governance dispute with China.\n\nThe US Representative expressed enthusiasm about the upcoming meeting with the Dalai Lama, emphasizing the significance of the bill passed by Congress.\n\nMeanwhile, China said on Tuesday that Beijing is \"gravely concerned\" over the visit of the US delegation to Dharamshala.\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian addressing a regular press conference yesterday asked the US to fully recognise the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Group and to \"stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" the Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson said.\n\n\"We are gravely concerned over the relevant reports and urge the US side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honour the commitments the US has made to China on issues related to Xizang, have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world,\" the Chinese Foreign Ministry said. China calls Tibet by the name Xizang.\n\nThe visiting US delegation visited the Tibetan Parliament in exile and the Tibet Museum Library of Tibetan Works and Archives in Gangchen Kyisjong in Dharamshala on Tuesday.\n\nThis report is auto-generated from a syndicated feed\n\nComments", "source": {"uri": "indiandefensenews.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "indiandefensenews.in"}, "authors": {"uri": "8185129527", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:37:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:37:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:36:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.newindianexpress.com/world/2024/Jun/19/things-have-changed-get-ready-for-that-us-lawmakers-to-china-after-meeting-dalai-lama-in-dharamshala", "title": "Things have changed, get ready for that: US Lawmakers to China after meeting Dalai Lama in Dharamshala", "body": "DHARAMSHALA: A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama Wednesday at his residence in Dharamshala,Himachal Pradesh,\n\nsparking anger from China which views the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism as a dangerous separatist.\n\nThis comes as Washington and Beijing have recently restarted talks after several years of turmoil that began after the imposition of tariffs on Chinese goods under the Trump administration. Relations at the time deteriorated even more following the COVID-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. There, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize said administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven U.S. lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the U.S. Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing. The bill should now be sent to the White House for President Joe Biden to sign into a law.\n\nPelosi said the bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" eliciting applause.\n\n\"It says to the Chinese government: 'Things have changed now, get ready for that\", she added.\n\nAhead of the visit, China's embassy in New Delhi criticised the meeting, saying the Dalai Lama was \"not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion\".\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said it reaffirmed American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. \"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or China will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what they may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the U.S. side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, including American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the U.S. on Thursday for medical treatment for his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the U.S. not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic {"uri": "8185697003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:05:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:05:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:05:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.deccanchronicle.com/news/us-delegation-pelosi-meets-dalai-lama-criticizes-xi-jinping-beijing-angered-899857", "title": "US Delegation, Pelosi Meets Dalai Lama, Criticizes Xi Jinping; Beijing Angered", "body": "According to media reports, the delegation led by Republican chairman of the House committee on foreign affairs Michael McCaul arrived earlier on Tuesday. The trip comes days after the US Congress passed a bill with bipartisan support that urged China to start dialogue with Tibetan leaders to find a solution to the longstanding conflict.\n\nMs Pelosi was quoted by media reports saying, \"The Dalai Lama will live a long time and his legacy will live forever, but you, the President (Mr Xi), will be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything... The Dalai Lama will not approve of my saying this...that I am criticising the Chinese government... But I hope he will indulge me today in saying change is on the way. As our colleagues have said, hope brings some faith and the faith of the Tibetan people, in the goodness of others, is going to make all the difference...\"\n\nMs Pelosi also reportedly said that bipartisan approval for the Resolve Tibet Act sends a message to China that Washington is clear in its thinking on this issue.\n\n\"This bill says to the Chinese government -- things have changed now, get ready for that,\" she was quoted as saying to cheering Tibetans at an event on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nAccording to media reports, the Resolve Tibet Act, which will put pressure on China to resume negotiations frozen for 14 years with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders, now only needs President Joe Biden's signature to become law. Reports from Beijing claim that Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Lin Jian has urged the US President not to sign the bipartisan Tibet Policy Bill adopted by both the US Senate and the House of Representatives.\n\nAt a public function on Wednesday after the meeting with the Dalai Lama, Mr McCaul reportedly said that the Chinese officials had sent the delegation a letter \"warning us not to come to Dharamsala\". He said the United States stands with Tibet in what he called its right to self-determination.\n\n\"America, the beautiful, will support Tibet to remain a powerful force as always,\" he was quoted by the media.\n\nIt may be noted that historically, the Dalai Lama, regarded for centuries as the supreme Tibetan spiritual leader, has always been chosen through a procedure rooted in the belief of reincarnation. The current Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, born in 1935 in Tibet and recognised as the 14th Dalai Lama, had fled to India as a young man way back in 1959 following a failed revolt in Tibet against Chinese rule.\n\nBased in Dharamsala, in Himachal Pradesh, his current health has reportedly been a cause for concern. It is due to this that the selection of the next Dalai Lama eventually is being seen as a potential flashpoint between Beijing and the current Dalai Lama's exiled followers in India, who had formed the Central Tibetan Administration, popularly known as the Tibetan government-in-exile based out of Dharamsala decades ago.\n\nAttacking the Dalai Lama, Beijing, which refers to Tibet by the Chinese name Xizang, had earlier on Tuesday said, \"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion. We urge the US side to fully recognise the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honour the commitments the US has made to China on issues related to Xizang and stop sending the wrong signal to the world... Xizang's affairs are purely China's domestic affairs and no external interference will ever be allowed... China will take resolute measures to firmly defend its sovereignty, security and development interests.\"", "source": {"uri": "deccanchronicle.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Deccan Chronicle"}, {"uri": "8187767455", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "22:11:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T22:11:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T22:10:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-06-21/china-says-dalai-lama-must-correct-his-views-/104005294", "title": "China says Dalai Lama must 'thoroughly correct' his political views", "body": "The Chinese foreign ministry says the Dalai Lama -- the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism -- must \"thoroughly correct\" his political views as a condition for contact with China's central government to resume.\n\nFormal talks between China and the Dalai Lama, who fled to India in 1959 after a failed Tibetan uprising against Chinese rule, and his representatives have been stalled since 2010.\n\n\"With regard to contact and negotiations between the central government of China and the 14th Dalai Lama, our policy has been consistent and clear,\" said Lin Jian, a spokesman at China's foreign ministry.\n\n\"The key is that the 14th Dalai Lama must fundamentally reflect on and thoroughly correct his political views,\" Mr Lin said at a regular ministry news conference.\n\nThe Dalai Lama stepped down in 2011 as the political leader of the Tibetan government-in-exile, which Beijing does not recognise and views as a violation of China's constitution.\n\nYet China continues to chafe at any interaction he has with officials of other countries, including former US presidents, even though the Dalai Lama says he is not seeking independence for Tibet.\n\nThe 88-year-old, whom China sees as a dangerous separatist in a monk's robes, remains the spiritual leader of the Tibetan people.\n\nUS politicians are currently asking President Joe Biden to sign the Resolve Tibet Act, a bill passed by the US congress last week and aimed at pressing China to secure a negotiated and peaceful agreement on Tibet.\n\nA group of US politicians, who met the Dalai Lama in India on Wednesday, said they would not allow China to influence the choice of his successor.\n\nWhile Washington recognises Tibet as a part of China, the bill appears to question that position, analysts say.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Representative Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived on Tuesday at the hillside town the Dalai Lama has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet.\n\nThere, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognise the said administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nMr McCaul, the Republican representative, said the bill reaffirmed American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination.\n\n\"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here ... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said.\n\nThe visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law\", or China will take \"resolute measures\", without elaborating on what they may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Mr Lin added, urging the US side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world\".\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and The disciples of the Dalai Lama were also seen in the temple complex this morning.\n\nChildren performed and displayed Tibetan culture at the felicitation ceremony in the courtyard of Tsuglagkhang Complex in Dharamshala.\n\nDuring their meeting at his residence in Dharamshala today, McCaul presented Dalai Lama with a framed copy of The Resolve Tibet Act, a bipartisan bill passed by the US Congress to enhance the US support for Tibet.\n\nDalai Lama presented Buddha Statue to Pelosi at the end of the meeting with the US Congressional delegation, the office of the Dalai Lama said.\n\nThe members of the US Congressional delegation also posed for a group photo with the Tibetan spiritual leader after their meeting.\n\nThe Congressional delegation arrived in India on Tuesday and was received by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at Himachal Pradesh's Kangra Airport the same day.\n\nLast week, the US Congress passed a bill urging Beijing to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nThe US House of Representatives passed the bill 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', also known as the 'Resolve Tibet Act', and it now heads to President Joe Biden for a signature to become law, Radio Free Asia reported.\n\nThe legislation rejects Beijing's stance that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and urges China to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama.\"\n\nIt also urged China to begin talks with the Dalai Lama, who is the spiritual leader of Tibet, and other Tibetan leaders about how Tibet is governed. No formal talks between the two sides have taken place since 2010.\n\nMeanwhile, China said on Tuesday that Beijing is \"gravely concerned\" over the visit of the US delegation to Dharamshala.\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian addressing a regular press conference yesterday asked the US to fully recognise the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Group and to \"stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" the Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson said. {"uri": "2024-06-394707794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:43:32", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:43:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:28:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://businessmirror.com.ph/2024/06/19/us-lawmakers-meet-with-dalai-lama-in-india-drawing-rebuke-from-china/", "title": "US lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama in India, drawing rebuke from China", "body": "By Ashwini Bhatia & Krutika Pathi | The Associated Press\n\nDHARAMSHALA, India -- A bipartisan United States congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama Wednesday at his residence in India's Dharamshala, sparking anger from China which views the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism as a dangerous separatist.\n\nThis comes as Washington and Beijing have recently restarted talks after several years of turmoil that began after the imposition of tariffs on Chinese goods under the Trump administration. Relations deteriorated even more following the Covid-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and in the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. There, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize the exiled administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven US lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing. The bill should now be sent to the White House to be signed into law by President Joe Biden.\n\nThe bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Pelosi said, eliciting applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said the bill reaffirms American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. \"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or China will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what these measures may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the US side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Associated Press writer Didi Tang in Washington contributed to this report. Pathi reported from New Delhi.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with US officials, including meeting American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nWhile India considers Tibet to be part of China, it hosts Tibetan exiles.", "source": {"uri": "businessmirror.com.ph", "dataType": "news", "title": "BusinessMirror"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8186131171", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "00:55:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T00:55:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T00:54:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/pelosi-hails-legacy-of-dalai-lama-hits-out-at-china-xi-101718821868561.html", "title": "Pelosi hails legacy of Dalai Lama, hits out at China, Xi", "body": "Former US House speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday accused China and President Xi Jinping of trying to erase Tibetan culture after a meeting with the Dalai Lama in Dharamshala, a day after Beijing, which calls the Tibetan spiritual leader a separatist, expressed concerns over the visit.\n\n\"(Chinese authorities) are trying to erase the culture, reduce the use of the language. They are attempting something we cannot let them get away with,\" Pelosi said.\n\n\"His Holiness Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live a long time and his legacy will live forever. But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything,\" the senior US lawmaker said in a comment pointedly about Xi.\n\nPelosi and a bipartisan group of US lawmakers, led by Republican chairman of the House committee on foreign affairs Michael McCaul, held an hour-long meeting with the Dalai Lama at his residence in McLeodganj and also met senior officials from Tibet's government-in-exile.\n\nThe visit comes days after the US Congress passed a bill urging China to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to resolve the dispute over the status of Tibet. The talks have been frozen since 2010.\n\nThe bill, a copy of which was presented to the Dalai Lama by the delegation, rejects China's contention that Tibet has been part of the country since ancient times and urges Beijing to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama\".\n\nAddressing a group of Tibetans after the meeting, Pelosi said the legislation passed last week sends a clear message to the Chinese government.\n\n\"We have clarity in our thinking and understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet...We know that the Chinese government is up to. They must get the message, and this legislation sends that message and it will be soon signed by President Biden,\" she said.\n\nMcCaul said, \"This bill makes it clear that the US believes that Tibet has its own unique language, religion and culture. It has a right to self-determination. The bill also requires the state department to aggressively challenge Chinese Communist Party (CCP) propaganda about Tibet.\"\n\nThe remarks come as Washington and Beijing seek to steady rocky ties, while India is engaged in a dragging military standoff with China on the Line of Actual Control (LAC) that has taken bilateral relations to a six-decade low.\n\nOfficials from the Tibetan government-in-exile earlier said the US visit and legislation will put pressure on China to engage with them as they seek autonomy for the region.\n\nCongressional approval of the bill is a significant breakthrough, said its leader Penpa Tsering, saying it would put pressure on Beijing to negotiate. But the Dalai Lama had always sought \"autonomy or a middle way, not independence\" for Tibet, he added.\n\nOn Tuesday, Beijing expressed serious concerns over the visit and urged US to \"fully recognise the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group.\"\n\nIt also warned the US against signing the bill into law, saying \"China will take resolute measures to firmly defend its sovereignty, security and development interests.\"\n\nMcCaul said the delegation, including Pelosi, had also received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning them against coming to Dharamshala.\n\n\"They repeated their false claim that Tibet has been a part of China since the 13th century but we did not let the CCP intimidate us, for we are here today. The Dalai Lama knows that this is not true, that Tibet is a part of China and the people of Tibet know that is not true. {"uri": "8186010146", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "22:21:55", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T22:21:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T22:12:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/international/2751895/", "title": "Nancy Pelosi and other US lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama, move likely to anger China - ExBulletin", "body": "A group of U.S. lawmakers met with Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in India on Wednesday, a move likely to anger China.\n\nThe visit came as President Joe Biden appears poised to sign a bill pressuring Beijing to resolve tensions with Tibet and protect the region's indigenous Buddhist culture.\n\nThe bipartisan delegation of seven lawmakers, led by Rep. Michael McCaul, Republican of Texas, and also including former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, arrived Tuesday in Dharamshala, a Himalayan town in northern India where the Dalai Lama, 88, has lived in exile since fleeing China in 1959 after the failure of the Tibetan uprising against Chinese rule.\n\nI still hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace, McCaul said after the meeting, according to Reuters.\n\nMcCaul said Tuesday that Biden would soon sign a bill passed by Congress last week that presses Beijing to resume negotiations with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders, frozen since 2010, and address the Tibetan people's concerns over their cultural, religious and linguistic autonomy. .\n\nA US congressional delegation met with the Dalai Lama on Wednesday. Leslie Shedd / AP\n\nThis bill says to the Chinese government: Things have changed now, prepare for this, cited Pelosi, whose 2022 visit to the Beijing-claimed island of Taiwan prompted China to encircle the island with live-fire military exercises after his departure, as he said on Wednesday.\n\nThe lawmakers' meeting with the Dalai Lama risks angering Beijing at a time when the United States and China are trying to improve relations. Beijing considers the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize winner to be an anti-China separatist, which he denies, and opposes any contact with him by foreign officials.\n\nChina's Foreign Ministry said on Tuesday that Tibet-related affairs are China's internal affairs and China will take resolute measures to defend its sovereignty, security and development interests.\n\nWe urge the US side to stick to its commitments to recognize Tibet as part of China and not support Tibetan independence, spokesperson Lin Jian said at a regular press briefing in Beijing. The United States should not sign the bill.\n\nThe Dalai Lama will travel to the United States this month to receive medical treatment for his knees, his office announced earlier. It is not yet clear whether he will meet with U.S. officials during his trip.\n\nUntil the presidency of Donald Trump, the Dalai Lama had met every sitting American president since George HW Bush. Biden, who criticized Trump during the 2020 campaign for his failure to meet with the Tibetan spiritual leader, has not met with the Dalai Lama since taking office in 2021.\n\nThe lawmakers' meeting with the Dalai Lama is aimed at making up for the Biden administration's reluctance to speak out on Tibet, said Brahma Chellaney, professor emeritus of strategic studies at the Center for Policy Research, a New Delhi think tank .\n\nThe United States and India must work together, including to counter China's misinformation about Tibet and thwart its plans to install a puppet as the next Dalai Lama, he said in an email to NBC News .\n\nLike the United States, India recognizes Tibet as part of China, although it hosts Tibetan exiles.\n\nMcCaul said Wednesday that the United States would not allow China to interfere in the process of appointing a successor to the Dalai Lama, considered a reincarnation of the Buddha, after his death.\n\nThere is already a dispute over who is the legitimate Panchen Lama, the second most important figure in Tibetan Buddhism, after the Dalai Lama and China's officially atheist government identified two different people as reincarnations in 1995.\n\nActivists say the Dalai Lamas' choice, a 6-year-old child, was kidnapped by the Chinese government days after being named and has been forcibly detained ever since.\n\nChina says Tibet has prospered and modernized under Communist Party rule, pointing to the construction of highways, high-speed railways and other infrastructure as well as the promotion of tourism.\n\nCritics say this has come at the cost of erasing Tibetan culture, language and religion, as Beijing Sinicizes the remote, mountainous region it annexed in the 1950s.\n\nSuch suffering and oppression inflicted on the Tibetan people by the Chinese Communist Party authorities is unprecedented and unprecedented, Penpa Tsering, chairman of the Tibetan government in exile, said last year.\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Relations at the time deteriorated even more following the COVID-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and the Taiwan Strait.\n\nDALAI LAMA SAYS HE WAS BEING 'INNOCENT AND PLAYFUL' WHEN ASKING YOUNG BOY TO 'SUCK MY TONGUE'\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Rep. Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959. There, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing doesn't recognize said administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven U.S. lawmakers addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the U.S. Congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing. The bill should now be sent to the White House for President Joe Biden to sign into a law.\n\nPelosi said the bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" eliciting applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said it reaffirmed American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination. \"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill have triggered swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington on Tuesday not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law,\" or China will take \"resolute measures,\" without elaborating on what they may be.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the U.S. side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with U.S. officials, including American presidents -- from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama -- except for Donald Trump. The Oracle Nechung is a major figure in Tibet and is Dalai Lama's advisor.\n\nFormer US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, top Republican Michael McCaul and other members of the US congressional delegation arrived at the Dalai Lama Temple to meet with the Tibetan spiritual leader on Wednesday.\n\nThe bipartisan US delegation, led by Michael McCaul, the Republican Chair of the US House Foreign Affairs Committee, was welcomed by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at Kangra Airport in Himachal Pradesh on Tuesday.\n\nPeople familiar with the developments said that the US delegation was taking part in rituals inside the Dalai Lama Temple. The Oracle Nechung also made sermons at ritual.\n\nThe Oracle Nechung, also known as the State Oracle of Tibet, is a significant spiritual figure in Tibetan Buddhism. The Nechung Oracle serves as the chief state oracle and advisor to the Dalai Lama and the Tibetan government-in-exile.\n\n\"It's very exciting to be here,\" Pelosi said, greeted by Tibetan schoolchildren and officials of the government-in-exile. In 2022, Speaker Pelosi's visit to Taiwan strained relations between the US and China.\n\nThe oracle's prophecies and advice have historically influenced significant decisions within the Tibetan government. The current Nechung Oracle, Thupten Ngodup, has served in this role since 1987.\n\n\"They are here to experience a different way of culture that Tibetans have...we are going to have the official get-together in the meeting...It sends (the message) that Tibet is not alone. The United States is with Tibet and human rights still matter. This is a message not only for Tibet but anybody who is aspiring for human rights and for freedom,\" the deputy speaker of Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, Dolma Tsering Teykhang, was quoted as saying by news agency ANI.\n\n\"All those who are suffering under the intimidation of China and the expansionist mentality of Xi Jinping, I think this is a very big message for them,\" Teykhang further added.\n\nEarlier this week, the US Congress approved a bill urging Beijing to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to resolve their dispute over Tibet peacefully.\n\nThe bill, called the 'Resolve Tibet Act,' passed in the US House of Representatives and now awaits President Joe Biden's signature to become law. McCaul confirmed that President Joe Biden intends to sign the 'Resolve Tibet Act', which was passed by Congress last week.\n\nAccording to a report by Radio Free Asia, the legislation rejects China's claim that Tibet has always been a part of China and calls on Beijing to stop spreading misinformation about Tibetan history, its people, and institutions, including the Dalai Lama.\n\nThe bill also urged China to start discussions with the Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of Tibet, and other Tibetan leaders about Tibet's governance. There have been no formal talks between the two sides since 2010.\n\nThe Chinese government, while reacting to the visit, termed the 'Dalai Group' as 'anti-China separatist'. Its foreign ministry spokesperson Lin Jian while addressing a regular press conference on Tuesday said: \"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion\".\n\n\"Stop sending the wrong signal to the world. We are gravely concerned over the relevant reports and urge the US side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honour the commitments the US has made to China on issues related to Xizang, have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world,\" Jian said, using the China-given name, Xizang, for Tibet.", "source": He would say, 'Let's pray that Nancy rids her of her negative attitudes.' But I hope it will allow me today to say that change is on the way. As our colleagues have said, hope brings a little faith and the faith of the Tibetan people, in the goodness of others,. will make all the difference...\" Ms. Pelosi said.\n\nShe also said that bipartisan approval of the Resolve Tibet Act sends a message to China that Washington has clear thinking on this issue. \"This bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, prepare for this,\" she told Tibetans at an event this afternoon.\n\nThe act - which will put pressure on China to resume 14-year-frozen negotiations with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders - is now just a few days away. needs President Joe Biden's signature to become law.\n\nMr Biden, unlike every American president since George HW Bush, has never met the Dalai Lama.\n\nTibetan officials, particularly the Central Tibetan Administration, or CTA, believe that the Resolve Tibet Act, once signed, will be a powerful reaffirmation of the United States' commitment to the Tibetan people.\n\nThe United States has long supported the Tibetan people's right to practice their religion and culture and accuses China of human rights abuses in the remote Himalayan region that borders India.\n\nBut confusingly, the United States also considers the Tibet Autonomous Region to be a part of China.\n\nMs Pelosi's stunning offensive not only strengthens India's position against China, it also comes as US President Joe Biden prepares to sign a bill pressing Beijing to resolve the Tibet conflict and highlights Washington's intention to prevent Beijing from intervening in the selection of the next Dalai Lama. Lama.\n\nTradition has it that the Dalai Lama is reincarnated after his death and the current leader - who turns 89 next month - has said his successor could be found in India. However, China insists that officially atheist communist leaders will appoint the next Dalai Lama, in keeping with a legacy of the past.\n\nThe US delegation - led by Congressman Gregory Meeks (D-NY) - arrived in India on Tuesday and met with Tibetan officials, Buddhist monks and nuns and schoolchildren at Kangra Airport in the Himachal Pradesh. The visit comes before the Dalai Lama's visit for treatment of a knee disease.\n\nTheir visit is significant because it comes as Washington and Beijing strive to improve relations between two of the world's economic and military giants. China has already expressed its irritation.\n\nBeijing considers the Dalai Lama, Nobel Peace Prize winner, a dangerous separatist and said it was \"seriously concerned\" by the visit of the American delegation and the bill which will be signed by Mr Biden.\n\nChina's Foreign Ministry said Tuesday that Tibet-related matters were an internal matter and that Beijing would take \"resolute measures\" to defend its sovereignty. \"We urge the American side to adhere to its commitments to recognize Tibet as part of China...\" a spokesperson told reporters in Beijing on Tuesday.\n\nThe American delegation, however, remained unmoved. Mr Meeks said: \"China can express its displeasure (but) we will stand up for what is right... to ensure that Tibetans have freedom, (that they) can return to their homeland and retain their culture and their history. That's what's important...\"\n\nBorn in 1935 as Lhamo Thondup, the Dalai Lama was identified as the reincarnation of his predecessor at the age of two and was enthroned in 1940 as the 14th Dalai Lama in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital.\n\nHe fled Tibet in 1959 and has since lived in McLeodganj, a small town near Dharamsala.\n\nHe believes in a \"middle\" approach, that is, greater autonomy versus At the time, relations further deteriorated following the COVID-19 pandemic and rising military tensions in the South China Sea and Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican Michael McCaul and including former Democratic House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived Tuesday in the hillside city that the Nobel Peace Prize winner has made his headquarters since he fled Tibet after the failure of an uprising against Chinese rule. in 1959. There, they met with officials of the Tibetan government in exile, which wanted more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing does not recognize the said administration and has not engaged in any dialogue with representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting with the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven U.S. lawmakers addressed hundreds of people gathered at a monastery just outside the Dalai Lamas' 88-year-old residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that one of the main purposes of their visit was to highlight the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US Congress last week, which aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials in the hope of finding a peaceful solution between Tibet and Tibet. Beijing. The bill is now expected to be sent to the White House for President Joe Biden to sign into law.\n\nPelosi said the bill is a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and understanding on this issue of Tibetan freedom, drawing applause.\n\nMcCaul, the Republican representative, said it reaffirmed U.S. support for the Tibetans' right to self-determination. Just this week, our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party warning us not to come here... but we did not allow ourselves to be intimidated by the CCP because we are here today, he said under people's applause.\n\nHowever, the visit and the recently passed bill triggered a swift response from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese Foreign Ministry, on Tuesday urged Washington not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House should not sign the bill, otherwise China would take resolute action, without specifying what they could be.\n\nEveryone knows that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the guise of religion, Lin added, urging the US side to have no contact with the Dalai Lama group in any way. form and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and the protection of Tibet's indigenous Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of dealings with U.S. officials, including U.S. presidents from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama to Donald Trump. He has yet to meet with Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the United States on Thursday to receive medical treatment for his knees, but it is unclear whether he will meet with officials during his stay.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the United States not to interfere in Tibetan affairs and has maintained that the Tibetan people have benefited from social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nWhile India considers Tibet part of China, it welcomes Tibetan exiles.\n\n___\n\nAssociated Press writer Didi Tang in Washington contributed to this report. {"uri": "8185050341", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "09:47:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T09:47:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T09:46:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/world-news/2024/06/19/us-delegation-meets-dalai-lama-in-india--sparking-anger-from-china/", "title": "US delegation meets Dalai Lama in India - sparking anger from China", "body": "Former US house speaker Nancy Pelosi was part of the American legislators' group visiting the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader.\n\nA bipartisan US congressional delegation has met the Dalai Lama at his residence in India's Dharamshala.\n\nThe move sparked anger from China, which views the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism as a dangerous separatist.\n\nThe visit came after Washington and Beijing restarted talks after several years of turmoil that began after the imposition of tariffs on Chinese goods under the Trump administration.\n\nRelations deteriorated even more following the Covid-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and in the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThe high-level delegation, led by Republican representative Michael McCaul and including Democratic former house speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived at the hillside town, which the Nobel Peace Prize laureate has made his headquarters since fleeing from Tibet after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959.\n\nThere, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing does not recognise the exiled administration and has not held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven US members of congress addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing.\n\nThe bill should now be sent to the White House to be signed into law by President Joe Biden.\n\nThe bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet\", Ms Pelosi said, eliciting applause.\n\nMr McCaul, the Republican representative, said the bill reaffirms American support for the Tibetan right to self-determination.\n\n\"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said, as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill triggered a swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law\", or China will take \"resolute measures\".\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Mr Lin added, urging the American side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world\".\n\nThe Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and says he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection for Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with US officials, including meeting American presidents - from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama - except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Mr Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while he is there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nWhile India considers Tibet to be part of China, it hosts Tibetan exiles.", "source": {"uri": "shropshirestar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Shropshire Star"}, The Act urges Beijing to engage with Tibetan leaders and resume talks, which have been halted since 2010, to resolve their governance disagreement with China peacefully.\n\nPelosi said, \"...His Holiness Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live a long time and his legacy will live forever. But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything.\"\n\n\"Dalai Lama would not approve of my saying that.... when I criticise the Chinese government, he says, let's pray for Nancy to rid her of her negative attitudes. I hope he will indulge me today to say that change is on the way. As our colleagues have said hope brings some faith and the faith of the Tibetan people in the goodness of others is what is going to make all the difference,\" Pelosi said.\n\nMeanwhile, China urged US President Joe Biden not to sign the Tibet policy bill, warning of \"resolute measures\", as it expressed \"strong concern\" over the visit of delegation to Dharamshala.\n\nBeijing, which calls the Dalai Lama a dangerous \"splittist\" or separatist, said it was seriously concerned about the visit and the bill.\n\nIt urged the U.S. lawmakers not to make contact with what it calls the \"Dalai clique\".\n\nThe Dalai Lama, an 88-year-old Nobel peace laureate, fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet. Since then, the Dalai Lama has been living a life in exile in India. Chinese officials, however, object to at any interaction he has with officials of other countries.\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has met U.S. officials, including presidents, during previous visits to the United States, but Biden has not met him since taking office in 2021.\n\nHe is due to fly to the U.S. this week for medical treatment, but it is unclear if he will have any engagements there during his stay there.
