{"uri": "2024-06-395288155", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "01:35:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T01:35:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T01:16:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.rfa.org/english/news/tibet/us-delegation-mccaul-06192024211534.html", "title": "Defying China, US lawmakers meet with Dalai Lama", "body": "Defying a warning from China, a delegation of U.S. lawmakers met with the Dalai Lama in Dharamsala, in northern India, on Wednesday, telling the Tibetan Buddhist spiritual leader that the recent passage of U.S. legislation is a major step toward ensuring the self-determination of the Tibetan people.\n\nLed by Rep. Michael McCaul, a Texas Republican and chair of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, the bipartisan delegation also visited the Central Tibetan Administration, or CTA, the Tibetan government-in-exile, which McCaul called \"the temple of democracy.\"\n\nTheir two-day trip comes a week after Congress passed legislation known as the Resolve Tibet Act urging Beijing to resolve the China-Tibet dispute through dialogue with the Dalai Lama or his representatives - a bill they said President Joe Biden is expected to sign into law in coming days.\n\nThe bill \"is a major shift in U.S. policy towards Tibet on a road of self-determination,\" McCaul told members of the CTA. \"The United Nations talks about how every people and every country has a right to self-determination and we believe the people of Tibet have that right as well.\"\n\nNo formal talks with Beijing on how Tibet should be governed have happened since 2010.\n\nMcCaul said he was \"so proud of the people of Tibet for having this temple of democracy in exile and I hope that one day this temple of democracy will be back in Tibet itself.\"\n\nUpon receiving a framed copy of the U.S. legislation on Tibet, the Dalai Lama thanked the delegation and called the bill \"very important.\"\n\nBipartisan delegation\n\nThe congressional delegation included former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi; Rep. Gregory Meeks, a Democrat from New York who is his party's ranking member on the Foreign Affairs Committee; Rep. Jim McGovern, a Democrat from Massachusetts who is also a member of the Congressional-Executive Commission on China.\n\nIt also included Rep. Ami Bera, a Democrat from California, Rep. Mariannette Miller-Meeks, an Iowa Republican, and Rep. Nicole Malliotakis, a Republican from New York.\n\n\"Our presence here today is also a symbol, a sign to Chinese leaders that America will never ever waver in our support for the Tibetan people,\" McGovern told the CTA.\n\nChina invaded the independent Himalayan country of Tibet in 1950 and has controlled the territory ever since. The Dalai Lama fled into exile in India amid a failed 1959 uprising against Chinese rule.\n\nSince then, Beijing has sought to legitimize Chinese rule through the suppression of dissent and policies undermining Tibetan culture and language. More recently, China has also sought to control the reincarnation process of Tibetan religious leaders in an attempt to interfere in the selection of the Dalai Lama's reincarnation.\n\n\"The Chinese Communist Party continues to threaten the freedom of the Tibetan people, and they have even attempted to insert themselves into the succession of the Dalai Lama,\" McCaul said.\n\nEarlier this week, the delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party warning them not to visit Dharamsala, McCaul said.\n\n\"But we did not let the CCP intimidate us, for we are here today,\" he said.\n\nChinese foreign ministry spokesperson Lin Jian on Tuesday criticized the trip.\n\n\"We are gravely concerned over the relevant reports and urge the U.S. side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honor the commitments the U.S. has made to China on issues related to Xizang, have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world,\" Lin Jian said at a media briefing, using a term that China has started to use to refer to Tibet.\n\nThe United States must not sign the bill into law and China will take steps to \"firmly defend its sovereignty, security and development interests,\" he added.\n\nBeijing believes the Dalai Lama wants to split off the Tibet Autonomous Region and other Tibetan-populated areas in China's Sichuan, Qinghai, Yunnan, and Gansu provinces from the rest of the country.\n\nHowever, the Dalai Lama does not advocate for independence but rather proposes what he calls a \"Middle Way\" that accepts Tibet's status as a part of China and urges greater cultural and religious freedoms, including strengthened language rights.\n\n\"We all are (the) same human being and we all have the same right. And this world belongs to humanity,\" he told the delegates at his residence.\n\n\"So we should take care of this world, irrespective of what religion or tradition (one belongs to). People of the world should be peaceful, happy,\" he said. \"That's our goal.\"\n\nGreeted warmly\n\nUpon their arrival Tuesday at Dharamsala's Gaggal Airport, the delegation was greeted by hundreds of cheering Tibetans who were waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nLater that day and next, as the delegation visited the Central Tibetan Administration and the Tibet Museum, and participated in a public ceremony organized by the CTA.\n\n\"The Tibetan people possess a distinct religion, culture and historic identity and they should have a say in their own future. You should be able to freely practice your religion and that is why we are here today in defiance of CCP's warning,\" McCaul said at the ceremony.\n\nPelosi, the former House speaker, also underscored the importance of the Resolve Tibet Act.\n\n\"We had been fighting for this (bill) for a long time,\" she said.\n\n\"This bill is a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Pelosi said.\n\nThe legislation rejects Beijing's position that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and calls on Beijing to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama.\"\n\n\"This message of the U.S. Congress should reach out to other governments,\" Sikyong Penpa Tsering, the democratically elected leader of the Central Tibetan Administration.\n\n\"I have also spoken with the State Department that once this becomes law then it's incumbent upon them to work with like-minded countries to make sure that similar resolutions or similar statements or similar laws are adopted in other nations,\" Tsering added.\n\nPelosi presented the Dalai Lama with a painting of the dome of the Capitol, which she said should serve as a constant reminder of the many friends he has there.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8186270463", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "03:49:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T03:49:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T03:46:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/explained-why-us-lawmakers-meeting-with-dalai-lama-in-india-has-miffed-china/articleshow/111126268.cms", "title": "Explained: Why US lawmakers meeting with Dalai Lama in India has miffed China | India News - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: The United States lawmakers' visit to Himachal's Dharamshala has riled up China as the bipartisan group from Washington met the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama on Wednesday.\n\nReacting to the visit to the Dalai Lama who China considers a \"separatist\", Beijing fumingly urged the United States to \"fully recognise the anti-China and separatist nature of the Dalai clique\" and refrain from \"any form of contact with it\".\n\nWhy US delegation visited India?\n\nThe seven-member group of American lawmakers visited India to meet the Nobel peace laureate Tenzin Gyatso - the 14th Dalai Lama in Himachal Pradesh's Dharamshala.\n\nThe US delegates meeting the Dalai Lama is part of Washington's decades-long support to the Tibetian people and their rights to practice religion and culture that China has suppressed through its actions violating human rights in the Tibetian region.\n\nA bipartisan bill passed this month by the US House of Representatives seeks to push Beijing to hold dialogue with Tibetan leaders that has been stalled since 2010. The goal is to secure a negotiated agreement on Tibet and address Tibetan aspirations related to historical, cultural, religious, and linguistic identity.\n\nAmong the delegation supporting the bill are its two authors and Nancy Pelosi, the former speaker of the US House of Representatives. The act is titled 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act' or the Resolve Tibet Act.\n\nThe delegation also met officials of Tibet's government in exile, which functions from India.\n\nWho is Dalai Lama?\n\nLhamo Thondup, also known as Tenzin Gyatso, was born in 1935 and was identified as the reincarnation of his predecessor at the age of two. He was enthroned in 1940 as the 14th Dalai Lama in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital.\n\nThe situation went haywire for the Tibetans and those who posed their faith in the 14th Dalai Lama after China invaded Tibet in 1950.\n\nThe Dalai Lama escaped to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against its rule. He has lived in exile in the Himalayan town of Dharamsala since then. In 1989, he was even awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.\n\nWhy has the visit become controversial?\n\nThe US lawmakers meeting Dalai Lama has infuriated China as the meeting comes at a time when Beijing and the US are struggling to improve its all-time low tie -- which is likely to descend deeper.\n\nMeanwhile, India and China are also having one of the frostiest phases in their bilateral relations ever since the 2016 Doklam and the 2020 Galwan standoffs.\n\nUS President Joe Biden is expected to sign the Resolve Tibet Act soon, aiming to address the ongoing dispute. Although Washington considers the Tibetan Autonomous Region to be part of China, the Act proposes that Tibetans have a say in their own future.\n\n\"This visit should highlight the bipartisan support in the U.S. Congress for Tibet to have a say in their own future,\" said Michael McCaul, the chief of the US delegation and one of the bill's authors, before departing from Washington on Friday.\n\nWhy China objects?\n\nChina sees Dalai Lama as a \"splittist\" or a separatist, which the Dalai Lama refuses, saying he only wants genuine autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing says it will approve a successor to the current Dalai Lama -- a move which would strengthen its control over the Himalayan region. Whereas, the Dalai Lama asserts that only the Tibetan people can make that call, and his successor could be found in India.\n\n(With Reuters inputs)\n\nThe TOI News Desk comprises a dedicated and tireless team of journalists who operate around the clock to deliver the most current and comprehensive news and updates to the readers of The Times of India worldwide. With an unwavering commitment to excellence in journalism, our team is at the forefront of gathering, verifying, and presenting breaking news, in-depth analysis, and insightful reports on a wide range of topics. The TOI News Desk is your trusted source for staying informed and connected to the ever-evolving global landscape, ensuring that our readers are equipped with the latest developments that matter {"uri": "8185389204", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:25:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:25:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:24:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/nancy-pelosi-dalai-lama-meeting-china-india-b2565314.html", "title": "Nancy Pelosi meets with Dalai Lama in latest move expected to anger China", "body": "The former speaker, along with a bipartisan delegation of seven lawmakers, traveled on Tuesday to Dharamshala, a Himalayan town in northern India where the Dalai Lama, 88, has lived in exile since fleeing China in 1959 after a failed Tibetan uprising against Chinese rule, to meet with the spiritual leader.\n\nThe meeting came as Joe Biden prepares to sign a bill pressuring Beijing to resolve tensions with Tibet and protect the region's native Buddhist culture.\n\n\"This bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, get ready for that,\" Pelosi said.\n\n\"It is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" Rep. Michael McCaul of Texas, who led the delegation, added after the meeting.\n\nThe bill, passed by Congress last week, presses Beijing to resume negotiations with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders that have been frozen since 2010, and to address Tibetan people's concerns about their cultural, religious and linguistic autonomy.\n\nChina governs most of Tibet, which it claims has been part of the country since ancient times. Although the US recognizes Tibet as part of China, the Dalai Lama had met with every US president up until Donald Trump. Joe Biden has not met with the Dalai Lama.\n\nDuring the meeting, lawmakers presented the spiritual leader with a framed copy of the \"Resolve Tibet Act\" which condemns \"all oppression and coercion of Tibetans\" and affirms their right to self determination.\n\nWednesday's meeting came at a time when the US is trying to improve its relations with China following the Covid-19 pandemic. However, the move will anger China, which sees the Dalai Lama as an anti-China \"separatist\" - an accusation he denies. China also opposes any contact with the 1989 Nobel Peace laureate by foreign officials.\n\nThe Chinese Foreign Ministry said Tuesday that affairs related to Tibet were an internal Chinese matter and that China would take \"resolute measures\" to defend its sovereignty, security and development interests.\n\nThe ministry also urged the US not to sign the bill into law. \"We urge the US side to adhere to its commitments of recognizing Tibet as part of China and not supporting 'Tibet independence,'\" spokesperson Lin Jian said at a regular news briefing in Beijing. \"The US must not sign the bill into law.\"\n\nWashington's relations with Beijing first began to deteriorate when then-president Trump imposed tariffs on Chinese goods.\n\nNancy Pelosi visited Taiwan in 2022, prompting China to encircle the island with live-fire military drills after she left. Taiwan, a democracy with more than 20 million inhabitants, has been independent since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949 but is claimed by the People's Republic of China.\n\nSince coming to power, Joe Biden has taken a more cautious approach to US-Chinese relations, making efforts to improve relations with Beijing.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and argues that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the United States on Thursday for medical treatment for his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while there.", "source": {"uri": "independent.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Independent"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8185051872", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "09:48:51", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T09:48:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T09:47:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/worldnews/2024/06/19/us-delegation-meets-dalai-lama-in-india-sparking-anger-from-china/", "title": "US delegation meets Dalai Lama in India - sparking anger from China", "body": "A bipartisan US congressional delegation has met the Dalai Lama at his residence in India's Dharamshala.\n\nThe move sparked anger from China, which views the exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism as a dangerous separatist.\n\nThe visit came after Washington and Beijing restarted talks after several years of turmoil that began after the imposition of tariffs on Chinese goods under the Trump administration.\n\nRelations deteriorated even more following the Covid-19 pandemic and the rising military tensions in the South China Sea and in the Taiwan Strait.\n\nThere, they met with officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nBeijing does not recognise the exiled administration and has not held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.\n\nAfter meeting the spiritual leader on Wednesday, the seven US members of congress addressed hundreds who had gathered at a monastery just outside the 88-year-old Dalai Lama's residence, waving American and Tibetan flags.\n\nThey told the crowd that a key focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US congress last week, and aims to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials with the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing.\n\nThe bill should now be sent to the White House to be signed into law by President Joe Biden.\n\nThe bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet\", Ms Pelosi said, eliciting applause.\n\n\"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said, as people cheered.\n\nHowever, the visit and newly passed bill triggered a swift backlash from Beijing.\n\nLin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, urged Washington not to support Tibetan independence and said the White House \"must not sign the bill into law\", or China will take \"resolute measures\".\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Mr Lin added, urging the American side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world\".\n\nThe Tibetan spiritual leader has a history of engaging with US officials, including meeting American presidents - from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama - except for Donald Trump. He has yet to meet Mr Biden since he took office in 2021.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is expected to travel to the US on Thursday for medical treatment on his knees, but it is unclear if he will meet any officials while he is there.\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing has repeatedly asked the US not to interfere with Tibetan affairs and has argued that the people of Tibet have enjoyed social stability and economic growth under its rule.\n\nWhile India considers Tibet to be part of China, it hosts Tibetan exiles.", "source": {"uri": "jerseyeveningpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jersey Evening Post"}, Asks US to Respect Its Sensitivities over Tibet | LatestLY", "body": "Beijing, Jun 20 (PTI) China on Thursday asked the Dalai Lama to thoroughly reflect and completely correct his political propositions for it to hold talks with him and asked the US to respect its sensitivity and importance to Tibet-related issues as Washington is set to pass a tough Tibet policy law.\n\nOn the central government's contact and talks with the 14th Dalai Lama China's policy is consistent and clear, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian told a media briefing.\n\nAlso Read | India Has No Right To Question References Made on Jammu and Kashmir in Pak-China Joint Statement, Says Pakistan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs.\n\nThe key is that the 14th Dalai Lama must thoroughly reflect on and completely correct his political propositions, he said, without elaborating.\n\nChina watched warily the high-powered US Congressional delegation's visit to Dharamsala and its meeting with the 88-year-old Dalai Lama besides the strong remarks made by its leading members US House Foreign Affairs Committee chair Michael McCaul and former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi questioning China's policy towards Tibet and their call to Beijing to hold talks with the Dalai Lama.\n\nAlso Read | Toyota and Yamaha's Imported Vehicles Probed by South Korean Government Over Fraudulent Japanese Testing.\n\nTheir visit came as US President Joe Biden was set to sign the Tibet policy bill adopted by both the US Senate and the House of Representatives. The bill awaits Biden's signature to make it into law.\n\nThe bill seeks to counter China's narrative about its control over Tibet and promote dialogue between the Chinese government and the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, who is based in India since he fled the Himalayan region in 1959.\n\nOn Tuesday, Beijing urged Biden not to sign the Tibet policy bill, warning of \"resolute measures\".\n\nOn the US delegation's visit to Dharamsala and its talks with the Dalai Lama, Lin said, \"We urge the US to clearly see the sensitivity and importance of Xizang-related issues and earnestly respect China's core interests on its comments on Xizang, refrain from any forms with the Dalai group and stop sending out to the world wrong signals.\"\n\nHe also criticised the reported remarks by the Tibet government-in-exile that it is going to use the new Tibet legislation passed by the US Senate and Congress to try to force China to come to the negotiating table and urge other countries to put pressure on Beijing to hold talks with it.\n\n\"The so-called Tibet government-in-exile is an out-and-out separatist political group and an illegal organisation in total violation of China's constitution and laws. It is not recognised by any country,\" Lin said.\n\nAfter the US Congressional talks with the Dalai Lama, McCaul said on Wednesday that the Tibetans have the right to self-determination and should be allowed to practise their religion freely.\n\nAt a felicitation ceremony held after the seven US Congress members met the Tibetan leader, McCaul said the delegation had defied a warning from the Chinese Communist Party.\n\n\"The Tibetan people possess a distant religion, culture and historic identity and they should have a say in their own future. You should be able to freely practise your religion and that is why we are here today in defiance of the CCP (Communist Party of China) warning,\" he said.\n\n\"Our delegation received a letter from the CCP warning us not to come here. They repeated their false claim that Tibet is part of China since the 13th century but we did not let the CCP intimidate us and we are here today,\" he said at the event organised by the Dharamsala-based Central Tibetan Administration (CTA).\n\nHe added that the Dalai Lama, the people of Tibet and the US know that Tibet is not part of China.\n\nThe US delegation included Mariannette Miller, Gregory Meeks, Nicole Malliotakis, Jim McGovern and Ami Bera.\n\nAt his residence, the Dalai Lama told them that he wanted the people of the world to be happy and peaceful.\n\nReferring to the Tibet policy bill, McCaul said at the later event that the timing of the visit could not be better. The bill also required aggressively challenging the CCP propaganda on Tibet, he added.\n\n\"I presented the Dalai Lama with a wind chime, which will remind him of our support,\" he said.\n\n\"Like many of you, I wish that this meeting was happening in your homeland of Tibet, but 65 years ago you were forced to flee after the Chinese Communist Party annexed Tibet and slaughtered tens of thousands of Tibetan people,\" he said.\n\nThe delegation leader claimed that the CCP was determined to eliminate Tibetan culture and forcibly bring the Tibetan people under its control.\n\nThanks to the kindness of the Indian people, the Tibetans who fled their homeland are able to live freely in this country and practise their religion without fear of persecution.\n\n\"It is still my hope that one day His Holiness the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" McCaul said.\n\nHe said the CCP continued to threaten the freedom of the Tibetan people decades later, and accused {"uri": "8185160276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:58:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:58:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:57:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2988033-us-lawmakers-meet-dalai-lama-rile-china-amidst-tibet-controversy", "title": "U.S. Lawmakers Meet Dalai Lama, Rile China Amidst Tibet Controversy | Politics", "body": "A delegation of U.S. lawmakers met with the Dalai Lama in India's Dharamsala, angering Beijing. The visit underscores U.S. bipartisan support for Tibetan rights and aims to push Beijing into talks over Tibet's autonomy. China sees the Dalai Lama as a separatist and objects to foreign engagements with him.\n\nA delegation of U.S. lawmakers met the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama on Wednesday in India's northern town of Dharamsala.\n\nThe meeting annoyed Beijing, which urged the United States on Tuesday to \"fully recognise the anti-China and separatist nature of the Dalai clique\" and refrain from \"any form of contact with it\". WHY IS THE DELEGATION IN INDIA?\n\nThe bipartisan seven-member group of American lawmakers is visiting India to meet the Nobel peace laureate, the Dalai Lama. The United States has long supported the rights of the Tibetan people to practice their religion and culture, and has accused China of human rights violations in the remote Himalayan region that borders India.\n\nA bipartisan bill passed this month by the U.S. House of Representatives aims seeks to push Beijing to hold talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to secure a negotiated agreement on Tibet and spur China to tackle Tibetan aspirations on historical, cultural, religious and linguistic identity. Among the delegation are the two authors of the act, titled 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act' or the Resolve Tibet Act, along with Nancy Pelosi, the former speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives.\n\nThe delegation also met officials of Tibet's government in exile, which functions from India. WHO IS THE DALAI LAMA?\n\nBorn in 1935 as Lhamo Thondup, the Dalai Lama was identified as the reincarnation of his predecessor at the age of two, and enthroned in 1940 as the 14th Dalai Lama in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital. Beijing invaded Tibet in 1950, and the Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against its rule, since when he has lived in exile in the Himalayan town of Dharamsala.\n\nHe was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989. WHY IS THE VISIT CONTROVERSIAL?\n\nIt has riled China at a time when Beijing and Washington are struggling to improve ties, and India's relations with China have also been strained since a military standoff on their Himalayan frontier killed 24 soldiers in 2020. U.S. President Joe Biden is expected to sign the Resolve Tibet Act soon, in a bid to find a resolution for the dispute, although Washington considers the Tibetan Autonomous Region to be a part of China.\n\n\"This visit should highlight the bipartisan support in the U.S. Congress for Tibet to have a say in their own future,\" the chief of the U.S. delegation, and one author of the bill, Michael McCaul, said ahead of his departure from Washington on Friday. WHAT ARE CHINA'S OBJECTIONS?\n\nChina accuses the Dalai Lama of being a \"splittist\" or a separatist, but he says he wants genuine autonomy for his remote Himalayan homeland. While Beijing has always objected to his meetings with foreign leaders, this has not prevented the Dalai Lama from meeting them, including U.S. presidents, although Biden has not met him yet.\n\nHowever, the most contentious issue is the task of appointing his successor. While Beijing has said it has the right to approve a successor, in a move set to strengthen its control over Tibet, the Dalai Lama says only the Tibetan people can make that call, and his successor could be found in India.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8185155079", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "10:55:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T10:55:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T10:54:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.gmanetwork.com/news/topstories/world/910563/us-lawmakers-meet-tibet-s-dalai-lama-pressure-china-on-talks/story/", "title": "US lawmakers meet Tibet's Dalai Lama, pressure China on talks", "body": "DHARAMSALA, India -- A group of US lawmakers who met the Dalai Lama in India on Wednesday said they would not allow China to influence the choice of his successor, comments expected to anger Beijing, which calls the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader a separatist.\n\nThe remarks come as Washington and Beijing seek to steady rocky ties while India pushes China to secure lasting peace on their disputed Himalayan frontier, four years after a military clash strained ties.\n\nThe lawmakers also signaled that Washington would pressure Beijing to hold talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to resolve the Tibet issue, with a bill they said President Joe Biden would sign soon.\n\nAlthough Washington recognizes Tibet as a part of China, the bill appears to question that position and any change would be a major shock to Beijing, analysts said.\n\nThe bipartisan group of seven, led by Michael McCaul, a Republican representative from Texas, who also chairs the House foreign affairs committee, met the Nobel peace laureate at his monastery in the northern Indian town of Dharamsala.\n\n\"It is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" McCaul told a public reception after the meeting.\n\nBeijing has even attempted to insert itself into choosing the successor of the Dalai Lama, he said, but added, \"We will not let that happen.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet. The 88-year-old, who has battled health problems for years, is set to fly to the United States this week for medical treatment.\n\nThe question of the Dalai Lama's successor has been a thorny issue, which analysts say highlights the power and influence of the role, fuelling Beijing's tussle to control it.\n\nTibetan tradition holds that the Dalai Lama is reincarnated after his death, and the current leader has said his successor may be found in India.\n\nBeijing has said the tradition must continue but its officially atheist Communist leaders have the right to approve the successor, as a legacy inherited from China's emperors.\n\nTibetans hail breakthrough\n\nThe US group, which includes Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived on Tuesday for a two-day visit.\n\nPelosi said Congress approval of the legislation, titled the 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', or the Resolve Tibet Act, sent a message to China that Washington was clear in its thinking on the issue of Tibet.\n\n\"This bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, get ready for that,\" she said to cheers from hundreds of Tibetans at Wednesday's event.\n\nPhotographs on the Dalai Lama's website showed him holding a framed copy of the bill as the lawmakers stood alongside.\n\nBeijing, which calls the Dalai Lama a dangerous \"splittist\" or separatist, has said it was seriously concerned about the bill and the lawmakers' visit, urging them not to contact what it calls the \"Dalai clique\" and Biden not to sign the bill.\n\nThe Indian foreign ministry offered no immediate comment on the lawmakers' visit.\n\nTies between the Asian rivals have been strained over their long mountainous border since army clashes in 2020 killed 20 Indian and four Chinese troops.\n\nAt the same time, concerns about China's growing might, among others, have nudged New Delhi and Washington closer in the last two decades.\n\nWhile Chinese officials chafe at any interactions of the Dalai Lama with officials of other countries, Biden has not met the Tibetan leader since taking office in 2021 and it is not clear if his treatment plans will allow time for engagements.\n\n\"Presidential assent for the bill would be far more concerning for China than whether Biden or any other leader meets the Dalai Lama,\" said Tibet specialist Robert Barnett of London's School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS).\n\nCongressional approval of the bill was a \"significant breakthrough,\" said Penpa Tsering, the political leader of the exiled Tibetan government, who believed it would put pressure on Beijing to negotiate.\n\nBut the Dalai Lama had always sought \"autonomy or a middle way, not independence\" for Tibet, he added. -- Reuters", Although Washington recognises Tibet as a part of China, the bill appears to question that position and any change would be a major shock to Beijing, analysts said.\n\nThe bipartisan group of seven, led by Michael McCaul, a Republican representative from Texas, who also chairs the House foreign affairs committee, met the Nobel peace laureate at his monastery in the northern Indian town of Dharamsala. \"It is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" McCaul told a public reception after the meeting.\n\nBeijing has even attempted to insert itself into choosing the successor of the Dalai Lama, he said, but added, \"We will not let that happen.\" The Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet. Tibetan tradition holds that the Dalai Lama is reincarnated after his death, and the current leader has said his successor may be found in India.\n\nBeijing has said the tradition must continue but its officially atheist Communist leaders have the right to approve the successor, as a legacy inherited from China's emperors. Photographs on the Dalai Lama's website showed him holding a framed copy of the bill as the lawmakers stood alongside.\n\nBeijing, which calls the Dalai Lama a dangerous \"splittist\" or separatist, has said it was seriously concerned about the bill and the lawmakers' visit, urging them not to contact what it calls the \"Dalai clique\" and Biden not to sign the bill. The Indian foreign ministry offered no immediate comment on the lawmakers' visit.\n\nTies between the Asian rivals have been strained over their long mountainous border since army clashes in 2020 killed 20 Indian and four Chinese troops. At the same time, concerns about China's growing might, among others, have nudged New Delhi and Washington closer in the last two decades.\n\nWhile Chinese officials chafe at any interactions of the Dalai Lama with officials of other countries, Biden has not met the Tibetan leader since taking office in 2021 and it is not clear if his treatment plans will allow time for engagements. \"Presidential assent for the bill would be far more concerning for China than whether Biden or any other leader meets the Dalai Lama,\" said Tibet specialist Robert Barnett of London's School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS).\n\nCongressional approval of the bill was a \"significant breakthrough\", said Penpa Tsering, the political leader of the exiled Tibetan government, who believed it would put pressure on Beijing to negotiate. {"uri": "8184909240", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:13:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:13:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:12:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/former-us-house-speaker-nancy-pelosi-dalai-lama-tibet-dharamshala-13783903.html", "title": "'Change is coming': Nancy Pelosi slams China for 'erasing' Tibet's culture", "body": "Former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi meets the Dalai Lama. PTI\n\nIn a heavily worded message to China from across the border, former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Wednesday said that \"change is on the way\" after she met the Dalai Lama in Himachal Pradesh's Dharamshala.\n\n\"His Holiness Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live a long time and his legacy will live forever. But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything,\" Pelosi said following her meeting with the exiled spiritual leader as part of a high-level US delegation visit to the town.\n\nShe added, \"Dalai Lama would not approve of my saying that when I criticize the Chinese government, he says, let's pray for Nancy to rid her of her negative attitudes. I hope he will indulge me today to say that change is on the way.\"\n\nThe visit comes as the US and China have increased talks in recent months, in a bid to normalize strained ties. But news of the visit and the subject of the bill triggered swift backlash from China.\n\nAfter their arrival on Tuesday, the delegation met officials from the Tibetan government-in-exile, which wants more autonomy for Tibet.\n\nResolve Tibet Act\n\nThe meeting between the Dalai Lama and Republican Rep. Michael McCaul-led delegation reportedly focused on the Resolve Tibet Act, recently passed by the US Congress, aimed at encouraging dialogue between the Dalai Lama and Chinese officials that could result in a peaceful resolution to the dispute between Tibet and Beijing. The bill will now go to the White House for President Joe Biden's endorsement.\n\nThe former US House Speaker said, \"You heard our colleagues talk about this legislation passed last week. We had been fighting this for a long time and in the spirituality of His Holiness, with manoeuvring inside the Congress, we made progress. But it's different now with the passage of this bill (Resolve Tibet Act) because this bill is a message to the Chinese Government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet.\"\n\nPelosi also said that during one of her visits to Tibet, she found that the Chinese government is trying to erase the culture of the region by reducing the use of the language.\n\n\"We saw the room where His Holiness grew up&mldr; They are trying to erase the culture by reducing the use of the language. They are trying something that we cannot let them get away with,\" she said.\n\nVisit irks China\n\nMeanwhile, Beijing, who has repeatedly warned Washington not to interfere with Tibetan affairs, on Tuesday warned of \"resolute measures\" if the US signs the Resolve Tibet Act into law.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson, Lin Jian said.\n\nHe added, \"We are gravely concerned over the relevant reports and urge the US side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honor the commitments the US has made to China on issues related to Xizang, have no contact with the Dalai group in any But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything,\" said the former US House Speaker.\n\nPelosi said that the Dalai Lama would not approve of her comment against the Chinese. \"When I criticize the Chinese government, he says, let's pray for Nancy to rid her of her negative attitudes,\" Pelosi said during the public felicitation programme at Tsuglagkhang Complex in Dharamshala.\n\nThe bipartisan Congressional delegation arrived in India on Tuesday and was received by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at Himachal Pradesh's Kangra Airport the same day.\n\nLast week, the US Congress passed a bill urging Beijing to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nThe US House of Representatives passed the bill 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', also known as the 'Resolve Tibet Act', and it now heads to President Joe Biden for a signature to become law, Radio Free Asia reported.\n\n\"You heard our colleagues talk about this legislation that was passed last week. We had been fighting this for a long time and in the spirituality of His Holiness, with manoeuvring inside the Congress, we made progress. But it's different now with the passage of this bill (Resolve Tibet Act) because this bill is a message to the Chinese Government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Pelosi said.\n\nPelosi further recalled the visit of the Chinese President to Washington, DC where she told him that the US is \"objecting\" to what China is doing to the culture of Tibet.\n\nIn response, Xi said, \"You know what you're talking about, you should go there and see for yourself all the improvements that China is making in Tibet,\" Pelosi recalled.\n\n\"They are trying to erase the culture by reducing the use of the language. They are trying something that we cannot let them get away with. I'll be gracious to the Chinese people, I don't know that they're up to this, but we do know that the Chinese government is, and we do know that they must get the message. This legislation sends the message, the House and the Senate and soon to be signed by Joe Biden, the president of the United States...\" the former US House Speaker added.\n\nUS Representative Congressman Gregory Meeks who is heading the American delegation's visit to India too gave a strong response to Beijing's criticism of their visit, and said that the US is going to stand for what is right.\n\n\"China can express unhappiness if it wants. We are going to stand for what is right. What is right is to make sure that Tibetans have freedom. They are able to return to their native land and they are able to keep their culture & history...That's what is important...\" he said.\n\nSikyong Penpa Tsering of the Central Tibetan Administration said \"no one can really make China happy.\"\n\n\"The meeting went on for about an hour. His Holiness (Dalai Lama) speaks about the larger interest of the society...He appreciated the US Congress people for passing the legislation,\" Penpa Tsering said on the meeting of the American delegation to Dharamshala.\n\nHe further said, \"Who can make China happy? They have to look at the reality and the situation and understand it from a better perspective...\"\n\nThe US legislation, notably rejects Beijing's stance that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and urges China to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama.\"\n\nIt also urged China to begin talks with the Dalai Lama, who is the spiritual leader of Tibet, and other Tibetan leaders about how Tibet is governed. No formal talks between the two sides have taken place since 2010.\n\nMeanwhile, China said on Tuesday that Beijing is \"gravely concerned\" over the visit of the US delegation to Dharamshala.\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian addressing a regular press conference yesterday asked the US to fully recognise the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Group and {"uri": "2024-06-394303944", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:56:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:56:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:50:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2987753-us-lawmakers-stand-firm-against-chinas-influence-over-dalai-lamas-successor", "title": "U.S. Lawmakers Stand Firm Against China's Influence Over Dalai Lama's Successor", "body": "U.S. lawmakers met with the Dalai Lama in India, stating they will not allow China to influence his successor. They also signaled Washington's pressure on Beijing to resume talks with Tibetan leaders. Beijing's attempts to decide the successor have been contentious, with the Dalai Lama fleeing to India in 1959.\n\nA group of U.S. lawmakers who met the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in India on Wednesday said they would not allow China to influence the choice of his successor, comments expected to anger Beijing which calls him a separatist. They also signalled that Washington would pressure Beijing to hold talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to resolve the Tibet issue with a bill President Joe Biden is expected to sign soon.\n\nThe bipartisan group of seven, led by Michael McCaul, a Republican representative from Texas, who also chairs the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, met the Nobel peace laureate at his monastery in the northern town of Dharamsala. \"It is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" McCaul told a public reception after the meeting.\n\nBeijing has even attempted to insert itself into choosing the successor of the Dalai Lama, he said, but added, \"We will not let that happen.\" The Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet. Having suffered from health problems for years, the 88-year-old is set to fly to the United States this week for medical treatment.\n\nThe question of his successor has been a contentious and widely-debated issue. Beijing has said the tradition must continue and its officially atheist Communist leaders have the right to approve the successor, as a legacy inherited from China's emperors.\n\nTibetan tradition holds that the Dalai Lama is reincarnated after his death, and the current leader has said his successor may be found in India. The dispute indicates the power and influence attaching to the role and the tussle between Beijing and its rivals to control it, analysts say.\n\nThe U.S. group, which includes Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived on Tuesday to a warm reception from school children, Buddhist monks and nuns. Pelosi said that approval by Congress for the legislation, titled the 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', or the Resolve Tibet Act, sends a message to China that Washington is clear in its thinking on the issue of Tibet.\n\n\"This bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, get ready for that,\" Pelosi said to cheers from hundreds of Tibetans at Wednesday's event. Beijing, which calls the Dalai Lama a dangerous \"splittist\" or separatist, said it was seriously concerned about the visit of the lawmakers to Dharamsala and the bill.\n\nIt urged the lawmakers not to make contact with what it calls the \"Dalai clique\" and Biden not to sign the bill. Chinese officials chafe at any interactions of the Dalai Lama with officials of other countries, though he has met U.S. officials, including presidents, on previous U.S. visits.\n\nBiden, however, has not met the Dalai Lama since taking office in 2021 and it is not clear if the Tibetan leader will have any engagements during this month's visit.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse {"uri": "8186962897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:59:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:59:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:56:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/china-says-dalai-lama-must-correct-his-political-propositions-for-talks-asks-us-to-respect-its-sensitivities-over-tibet-4771303", "title": "China says Dalai Lama must correct his political propositions for talks; Asks US to respect its sensitivities over Tibet", "body": "Beijing, Jun 20 (PTI) China on Thursday asked the Dalai Lama to thoroughly reflect and completely correct his political propositions for it to hold talks with him and asked the US to respect its sensitivity and importance to Tibet-related issues as Washington is set to pass a tough Tibet policy law.\n\nOn the central government's contact and talks with the 14th Dalai Lama China's policy is consistent and clear, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian told a media briefing.\n\nThe key is that the 14th Dalai Lama must thoroughly reflect on and completely correct his political propositions, he said, without elaborating.\n\nChina watched warily the high-powered US Congressional delegation's visit to Dharamsala and its meeting with the 88-year-old Dalai Lama besides the strong remarks made by its leading members US House Foreign Affairs Committee chair Michael McCaul and former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi questioning China's policy towards Tibet and their call to Beijing to hold talks with the Dalai Lama.\n\nTheir visit came as US President Joe Biden was set to sign the Tibet policy bill adopted by both the US Senate and the House of Representatives. The bill awaits Biden's signature to make it into law.\n\nThe bill seeks to counter China's narrative about its control over Tibet and promote dialogue between the Chinese government and the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, who is based in India since he fled the Himalayan region in 1959.\n\nOn Tuesday, Beijing urged Biden not to sign the Tibet policy bill, warning of \"resolute measures\".\n\nOn the US delegation's visit to Dharamsala and its talks with the Dalai Lama, Lin said, \"We urge the US to clearly see the sensitivity and importance of Xizang-related issues and earnestly respect China's core interests on its comments on Xizang, refrain from any forms with the Dalai group and stop sending out to the world wrong signals.\" He also criticised the reported remarks by the Tibet government-in-exile that it is going to use the new Tibet legislation passed by the US Senate and Congress to try to force China to come to the negotiating table and urge other countries to put pressure on Beijing to hold talks with it.\n\n\"The so-called Tibet government-in-exile is an out-and-out separatist political group and an illegal organisation in total violation of China's constitution and laws. It is not recognised by any country,\" Lin said.\n\nAfter the US Congressional talks with the Dalai Lama, McCaul said on Wednesday that the Tibetans have the right to self-determination and should be allowed to practise their religion freely.\n\nAt a felicitation ceremony held after the seven US Congress members met the Tibetan leader, McCaul said the delegation had defied a warning from the Chinese Communist Party.\n\n\"The Tibetan people possess a distant religion, culture and historic identity and they should have a say in their own future. You should be able to freely practise your religion and that is why we are here today in defiance of the CCP (Communist Party of China) warning,\" he said.\n\n\"Our delegation received a letter from the CCP warning us not to come here. They repeated their false claim that Tibet is part of China since the 13th century but we did not let the CCP intimidate us and we are here today,\" he said at the event organised by the Dharamsala-based Central Tibetan Administration (CTA).\n\nHe added that the Dalai Lama, the people of Tibet and the US know that Tibet is not part of China.\n\nThe US delegation included Mariannette Miller, Gregory Meeks, Nicole Malliotakis, Jim McGovern and Ami Bera.\n\nAt his residence, the Dalai Lama told them that he wanted the people of the world to be happy and peaceful.\n\nReferring to the Tibet policy bill, McCaul said at the later event that the timing of the visit could not be better. The bill also required aggressively challenging the CCP propaganda on Tibet, he added.\n\n\"I presented the Dalai Lama with a wind chime, which will remind him of our support,\" he said.\n\n\"Like many of you, I wish that this meeting was happening in your homeland of Tibet, but 65 years ago you were forced to flee after the Chinese Communist Party annexed Tibet and slaughtered tens of thousands of Tibetan people,\" he said.\n\nThe delegation leader claimed that the CCP was determined to eliminate Tibetan culture and forcibly bring the Tibetan people under its control.\n\nThanks to the kindness of the Indian people, the Tibetans who fled their homeland are able to live freely in this country and practise their religion without fear of persecution.\n\n\"It is still my hope that one day His Holiness the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" McCaul said.\n\nHe said the CCP continued to threaten the freedom of the Tibetan people decades later, and accused China of interfering with the process of finding a successor to the Dalai Lama. Dalai Lama in India", "body": "A high-level US Congressional delegation met the Dalai Lama in India's hillside town of Dharamshala on Wednesday, angering China which calls the Tibetan leader a dangerous separatist.\n\nDemocratic former House speaker Nancy Pelosi and Republican representative Michael McCaul were among the top leaders from Washington who reached the Dalai Lama's scenic Indian exiled residence on Tuesday.\n\nThey took part in a high-level meeting and called for the freedom of Tibet from China.\n\nChina asserts that Tibet has been part of its territory for centuries although it only took firm control of the region after the Communist Party came to power in 1949.\n\nThe delegation of seven US lawmakers, led by Mr McCaul, the Republican chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, addressed hundreds who had gathered outside the monastery located outside the 88-year-old spiritual leader's residence.\n\nThey also visited the offices of the Tibetan government in exile seeking autonomy for Tibet within China.\n\nMr McCaul, the Republican representative, said the delegation had overcome intimidation from China to meet with the Dalai Lama, the leader in exile in India since the 1960s, as he underlined the American support for Tibet's right to self-determination.\n\n\"Just this week our delegation received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning us not to come here ... but we did not let the CCP intimidate us for we are here today,\" he said as people cheered.\n\nThe delegation members said they wanted to encourage dialogue between the Dalai Lama and the Chinese officials in the hopes of finding a peaceful resolution between Tibet and Beijing.\n\nAmong the list, the main focus of their visit was to underscore the Resolve Tibet Act, passed by the US Congress last week, and is now likely with the White House awaiting Joe Biden's signature to turn it into a law.\n\nMs Pelosi said the bill is \"a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet\", eliciting applause.\n\nIn an immediate backlash, the visit was condemned by Chinese officials on Tuesday, who warned of \"resolute measures\".\n\nA Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson asked Washington to not support Tibetan independence. The White House \"must not sign the bill into law\" or China will take \"resolute measures\", said Lin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a purely religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Mr Lin added, urging the US side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nThe charges by Beijing have been denied by the Dalai Lama who said he only advocates substantial autonomy and protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture.\n\nThis visit is the latest flashpoint in the US and Congress relationship, which reached a communication point recently after several years of turmoil and contentious escalations.\n\nBeijing does not recognise the exiled administration and hasn't held any dialogue with the representatives of the Dalai Lama since 2010.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-394619554", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:26:57", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:26:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:05:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.straitstimes.com/asia/explainer-why-has-a-visit-by-us-lawmakers-to-india-upset-china", "title": "Explainer: Why has a visit by US lawmakers to India upset China?", "body": "NEW DELHI - A delegation of U.S. lawmakers met the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama on Wednesday in India's northern town of Dharamsala.\n\nThe meeting annoyed Beijing, which urged the United States on Tuesday to \"fully recognise the anti-China and separatist nature of the Dalai clique\" and refrain from \"any form of contact with it\".\n\nWHY IS THE DELEGATION IN INDIA?\n\nThe bipartisan seven-member group of American lawmakers is visiting India to meet the Nobel peace laureate, the Dalai Lama.\n\nThe United States has long supported the rights of the Tibetan people to practice their religion and culture, and has accused China of human rights violations in the remote Himalayan region that borders India.\n\nA bipartisan bill passed this month by the U.S. House of Representatives aims seeks to push Beijing to hold talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to secure a negotiated agreement on Tibet and spur China to tackle Tibetan aspirations on historical, cultural, religious and linguistic identity.\n\nAmong the delegation are the two authors of the act, titled 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act' or the Resolve Tibet Act, along with Nancy Pelosi, the former speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives.\n\nThe delegation also met officials of Tibet's government in exile, which functions from India.\n\nWHO IS THE DALAI LAMA?\n\nBorn in 1935 as Lhamo Thondup, the Dalai Lama was identified as the reincarnation of his predecessor at the age of two, and enthroned in 1940 as the 14th Dalai Lama in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital.\n\nBeijing invaded Tibet in 1950, and the Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against its rule, since when he has lived in exile in the Himalayan town of Dharamsala.\n\nHe was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989.\n\nWHY IS THE VISIT CONTROVERSIAL?\n\nIt has riled China at a time when Beijing and Washington are struggling to improve ties, and India's relations with China have also been strained since a military standoff on their Himalayan frontier killed 24 soldiers in 2020.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden is expected to sign the Resolve Tibet Act soon, in a bid to find a resolution for the dispute, although Washington considers the Tibetan Autonomous Region to be a part of China.\n\n\"This visit should highlight the bipartisan support in the U.S. Congress for Tibet to have a say in their own future,\" the chief of the U.S. delegation, and one author of the bill, Michael McCaul, said ahead of his departure from Washington on Friday.\n\nWHAT ARE CHINA'S OBJECTIONS?\n\nChina accuses the Dalai Lama of being a \"splittist\" or a separatist, but he says he wants genuine autonomy for his remote Himalayan homeland.\n\nWhile Beijing has always objected to his meetings with foreign leaders, this has not prevented the Dalai Lama from meeting them, including U.S. presidents, although Biden has not met him yet.\n\nHowever, the most contentious issue is the task of appointing his successor.\n\nWhile Beijing has said it has the right to approve a successor, in a move set to strengthen its control over Tibet, the Dalai Lama says only the Tibetan people can make that call, and his successor could be found in India. {"uri": "8186528197", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:26:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:26:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T07:25:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://asianlite.com/2024/top-news/pelosi-praises-dalai-lamas-enduring-legacy-slams-xi-jinping/", "title": "Pelosi praises Dalai Lama's enduring legacy, slams Xi Jinping - Asian News from UK", "body": "Pelosi who is on a two-day visit to India said \"no one will give credit\" Xi for anything....reports Asian Lite News\n\nFormer US House Speaker Nancy Peolsi who is part of a US bipartisan delegation, which met with the Dalai Lama on Wednesday launched a broadside against Xi Jinping, stating that while the legacy of the Tibetan spiritual leader will live forever, the Chinese President will be gone in a few years.\n\nPelosi who is on a two-day visit to India said \"no one will give credit\" Xi for anything.\n\n\"His Holiness Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live a long time and his legacy will live forever. But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything,\" said the former US House Speaker.\n\nPelosi said that the Dalai Lama would not approve of her comment against the Chinese. \"When I criticize the Chinese government, he says, let's pray for Nancy to rid her of her negative attitudes,\" Pelosi said during the public felicitation programme at Tsuglagkhang Complex in Dharamshala.\n\nThe bipartisan Congressional delegation arrived in India on Tuesday and was received by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at Himachal Pradesh's Kangra Airport the same day.\n\nLast week, the US Congress passed a bill urging Beijing to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nThe US House of Representatives passed the bill 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', also known as the 'Resolve Tibet Act', and it now heads to President Joe Biden for a signature to become law, Radio Free Asia reported.\n\n\"You heard our colleagues talk about this legislation that was passed last week. We had been fighting this for a long time and in the spirituality of His Holiness, with manoeuvring inside the Congress, we made progress. But it's different now with the passage of this bill (Resolve Tibet Act) because this bill is a message to the Chinese Government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Pelosi said.\n\nPelosi further recalled the visit of the Chinese President to Washington, DC where she told him that the US is \"objecting\" to what China is doing to the culture of Tibet.\n\nIn response, Xi said, \"You know what you're talking about, you should go there and see for yourself all the improvements that China is making in Tibet,\" Pelosi recalled.\n\n\"They are trying to erase the culture by reducing the use of the language. They are trying something that we cannot let them get away with. I'll be gracious to the Chinese people, I don't know that they're up to this, but we do know that the Chinese government is, and we do know that they must get the message. This legislation sends the message, the House and the Senate and soon to be signed by Joe Biden, the president of the United States...\" the former US House Speaker added.\n\nUS Representative Congressman Gregory Meeks who is heading the American delegation's visit to India too gave a strong response to Beijing's criticism of their visit, and said that the US is going to stand for what is right.\n\n\"China can express unhappiness if it wants. We are going to stand for what is right. What is right is to make sure that Tibetans have freedom. They are able to return to their native land and they are able to keep their culture & history...That's what is important...\" he said.\n\nSikyong Penpa Tsering of the Central Tibetan Administration said \"no one can really make China happy.\"\n\n\"The meeting went on for about an hour. His Holiness (Dalai Lama) speaks about the larger interest of the society...He appreciated the US Congress people for passing the legislation,\" Penpa Tsering said on the meeting of the American delegation to Dharamshala.\n\nHe further said, \"Who can make China happy? They have to look at the reality and the situation and understand it from a better perspective...\"\n\nThe US legislation, notably rejects Beijing's stance that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and urges China to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama.\"\n\nIt also urged China to begin talks with the Dalai Lama, who is the spiritual leader of Tibet, and other Tibetan leaders about how Tibet is governed. No formal talks between the two sides have taken place since 2010.\n\nMeanwhile, China said on Tuesday that Beijing is \"gravely concerned\" over the visit of the US delegation to Dharamshala.\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian addressing a regular press conference yesterday asked the US to fully recognise the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Group and to \"stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\" (ANI)", "source": {"uri": "asianlite.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Local News for British Asian and Indian Community in London"}, "authors": The passage of this bill is a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet. This legislation would soon be signed by President Joe Biden,\" said Pelosi, adding that Jim McGovern, the author of the bill and part of the visiting US delegation, is \"the patron saint of our Tibet policy.\"\n\nShe said that the Chinese government was trying to erase Tibetan culture. \"They (China) are trying to erase Ti-betan culture by reducing the use of the Tibetan language. The ethnic Han population is being assimilated with the Tibetan population in Tibet. We have seen in Tibet that the Chinese government is trying to educate Tibetan children in the Chinese way to reduce the knowledge of Tibetan language. They (China) are trying something that we cannot let them get away with,\" said Pelosi.\n\nSending a stern message to President Xi Jinping of China, Pelosi said: \"His Holiness, the Dalai Lama with his compassion, purity of soul and love, will live for a long time and his legacy will liveforever. But, you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything,\" said Pelosi. House foreign affairs committee chairman Michael McCaul, who led the US delegation, said that the US would not allow China to interfere with the succession of the Dalai Lama. \"The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) continues to threaten the freedom of the Tibetan people and has even attempted to insert themselves into the succession of the Dalai Lama. But we won't let that happen,\" said McCaul.\n\nHe said that the Chinese government had threatened the delegation not to visit the Dalai Lama. \"The delegation received a letter from the CCP warning us not to come here. They sent a letter in whichthey repeated their false claim that Tibet has been a part of China since the 13th century. But we did not let the CCP intimidate us, for we are here today,\" said McCaul, adding that people of Tibet, the Dalai Lama and the United States know that Tibet is not part of China.\n\n\"The Tibetan people possess a distinctive religious culture and identity. You should have a say in your own future. This is why we are here today in defiance of that warning,\" he said. \"The timing of this visit couldn't be better. We are here just a week after the House of Representatives and the Congress passed the Resolve Tibet Act,\" said McCaul, adding that the bill will be signed by President Biden in the coming days.", {"uri": "8185819960", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "18:51:44", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T18:51:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T18:50:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3267298/us-lawmakers-meet-tibets-dalai-lama-say-wont-let-china-influence-choice-successor", "title": "US lawmakers meet Tibet's Dalai Lama, pressure China on talks", "body": "The remarks are expected to anger Beijing, as Washington seeks to use a new bill to pressure China on talks with Tibetan leaders\n\nA group of US lawmakers who met the Dalai Lama in India on Wednesday said they would not allow China to influence the choice of his successor, comments expected to anger Beijing, which calls the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader a separatist.\n\nThe remarks come as Washington and Beijing seek to steady rocky ties while India pushes China to secure lasting peace on their disputed Himalayan frontier, four years after a military clash strained ties.\n\nThe lawmakers also signalled that Washington would pressure Beijing to hold talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to resolve the Tibet issue, with a bill they said US President Joe Biden would sign soon.\n\nAlthough Washington recognises Tibet as a part of China, the bill appears to question that position and any change would be a major shock to Beijing, analysts said.\n\nThe bipartisan group of seven, led by Michael McCaul, a Republican congressman from Texas, who also chairs the House foreign affairs committee, met the Nobel peace laureate at his monastery in the northern Indian town of Dharamsala.\n\n\u201cIt is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\u201d McCaul told a public reception after the meeting.\n\nBeijing has even attempted to insert itself into choosing the successor of the Dalai Lama, he said, but added: \u201cWe will not let that happen.\u201d\n\nThe Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet. The 88-year-old, who has battled health problems for years, is set to fly to the United States this week for medical treatment.\n\nThe question of the Dalai Lama\u2019s successor has been a thorny issue, which analysts say highlights the power and influence of the role, fuelling Beijing\u2019s tussle to control it.\n\nTibetan tradition holds that the Dalai Lama is reincarnated after his death, and the current leader has said his successor may be found in India.\n\nBeijing has said the tradition must continue, but its officially atheist Communist leaders have the right to approve the successor, as a legacy inherited from China\u2019s emperors.\n\nThe US group, which includes Democratic former House speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived on Tuesday for a two-day visit.\n\nPelosi said Congress approval of the legislation, titled \u201cPromoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act\u201d, or the Resolve Tibet Act, sent a message to China that Washington was clear in its thinking on the issue of Tibet.\n\n\u201cThis bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, get ready for that,\u201d she said to cheers from hundreds of Tibetans at Wednesday\u2019s event.\n\nPhotographs on the Dalai Lama\u2019s website showed him holding a framed copy of the bill as the lawmakers stood alongside.\n\nBeijing, which calls the Dalai Lama a dangerous \u201csplittist\u201d or separatist, has said it was seriously concerned about the bill and the lawmakers\u2019 visit, urging them not to contact what it calls the \u201cDalai clique\u201d and Biden not to sign the bill.\n\nThe Indian foreign ministry offered no immediate comment on the lawmakers\u2019 visit.\n\nTies between the Asian rivals have been strained over their long mountainous border since army clashes in 2020 killed 20 Indian and four Chinese troops.\n\nAt the same time, concerns about China\u2019s growing might, among others, have nudged New Delhi and Washington closer in the last two decades.\n\nWhile Chinese officials chafe at any interactions of the Dalai Lama with officials of other countries, Biden has not met the Tibetan leader since taking office in 2021 and it is not clear if his treatment plans will allow time for engagements.\n\n\u201cPresidential assent for the bill would be far more concerning for China than whether Biden or any other leader meets the Dalai Lama,\u201d said Tibet specialist Robert Barnett of London\u2019s School of Oriental and African Studies (SOAS).\n\nCongressional approval of the bill was a \u201csignificant breakthrough\u201d, Penpa Tsering, the political leader of the exiled Tibetan government, said in an interview.\n\nHe said he believed it would put pressure on Beijing to negotiate and that it could serve as a precedent for other nations to adopt similar policies to Washington.\n\n\u201cThis will give us a tool to work with other governments,\u201d he said in his office in Dharamsala.\n\nBut the Dalai Lama had always sought \u201cautonomy or a middle way, not independence\u201d for Tibet, he added.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "South China Morning Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8187436137", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:05:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:05:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:05:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://theindependent.sg/dalai-lama-meeting-with-nancy-pelosi-sparks-tensions-with-china/", "title": "Dalai Lama meeting with Nancy Pelosi sparks tensions with China - Singapore News", "body": "In a diplomatic move sure to ruffle feathers in Beijing, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi met with Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, in Dharamshala, India, on Wednesday (June 19). This visit, involving a bipartisan delegation of seven lawmakers, is poised to escalate tensions between the US and China.\n\nThe delegation, led by Rep. Michael McCaul of Texas, arrived in Dharamshala on Tuesday. The visit coincides with President Joe Biden's anticipated signing of a new bill aimed at urging Beijing to address longstanding issues in Tibet.\n\nThis bill demands the protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture and calls for renewed negotiations with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders, which have been stalled since 2010.\n\nPelosi was forthright in her message: \"This bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, get ready for that.\" Her words were echoed by McCaul, who expressed hope that the Dalai Lama and his people would one day return to Tibet in peace.\n\nLawmakers presented the Dalai Lama with a framed copy of the \"Resolve Tibet Act,\" which condemns oppression of Tibetans and asserts their right to self-determination. This gesture underscores the US Congress's support for Tibetan autonomy.\n\nChina, which maintains that Tibet has been an integral part of its territory since ancient times, is predictably incensed. The Chinese Foreign Ministry swiftly condemned the meeting, reiterating that Tibet is an internal matter and warning of \"resolute measures\" to protect its sovereignty.\n\nThe ministry also urged the US not to sign the bill into law, emphasizing the need for Washington to honor its commitment to recognizing Tibet as part of China and not supporting Tibetan independence.\n\nThe backdrop to this meeting includes a broader context of fluctuating US-China relations. Diplomatic ties have been strained since the Trump administration imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, and Pelosi's controversial visit to Taiwan in 2022 further exacerbated tensions. During that visit, China responded with aggressive military drills around Taiwan, a self-governing democracy that Beijing claims as its own.\n\nDespite these frictions, President Biden has sought a more cautious and conciliatory approach towards China, aiming to mend relations post-pandemic. However, Beijing's repeated calls for non-interference in Tibetan affairs continue to clash with US legislative actions supporting Tibetan rights and autonomy.\n\nThe Dalai Lama is scheduled to travel to the United States on Thursday for medical treatment. It remains uncertain whether he will meet with any US officials during his visit. Such a meeting would undoubtedly add another layer of complexity to the already strained US-China relations.\n\nSources:\n\nUS lawmakers meet Tibet's Dalai Lama, say won't let China influence choice
