{"uri": "8186993703", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "12:18:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T12:18:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T12:14:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/china-says-dalai-lama-must-correct-his-political-propositions-for-talks-asks-us-to-respect-its-sensitivities-over-tibet/2139796/", "title": "China says Dalai Lama must correct his political propositions for talks; Asks US to respect its sensitivities over Tibet", "body": "The key is that the 14th Dalai Lama must thoroughly reflect on and completely correct his political propositions, he said, without elaborating.\n\nChina watched warily the high-powered US Congressional delegation's visit to Dharamsala and its meeting with the 88-year-old Dalai Lama besides the strong remarks made by its leading members US House Foreign Affairs Committee chair Michael McCaul and former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi questioning China's policy towards Tibet and their call to Beijing to hold talks with the Dalai Lama.\n\nTheir visit came as US President Joe Biden was set to sign the Tibet policy bill adopted by both the US Senate and the House of Representatives. The bill awaits Biden's signature to make it into law.\n\nThe bill seeks to counter China's narrative about its control over Tibet and promote dialogue between the Chinese government and the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama, who is based in India since he fled the Himalayan region in 1959.\n\nOn Tuesday, Beijing urged Biden not to sign the Tibet policy bill, warning of \"resolute measures\".\n\nOn the US delegation's visit to Dharamsala and its talks with the Dalai Lama, Lin said, \"We urge the US to clearly see the sensitivity and importance of Xizang-related issues and earnestly respect China's core interests on its comments on Xizang, refrain from any forms with the Dalai group and stop sending out to the world wrong signals.\" He also criticised the reported remarks by the Tibet government-in-exile that it is going to use the new Tibet legislation passed by the US Senate and Congress to try to force China to come to the negotiating table and urge other countries to put pressure on Beijing to hold talks with it.\n\n\"The so-called Tibet government-in-exile is an out-and-out separatist political group and an illegal organisation in total violation of China's constitution and laws. It is not recognised by any country,\" Lin said.\n\nAfter the US Congressional talks with the Dalai Lama, McCaul said on Wednesday that the Tibetans have the right to self-determination and should be allowed to practise their religion freely.\n\nAt a felicitation ceremony held after the seven US Congress members met the Tibetan leader, McCaul said the delegation had defied a warning from the Chinese Communist Party.\n\n\"The Tibetan people possess a distant religion, culture and historic identity and they should have a say in their own future. You should be able to freely practise your religion and that is why we are here today in defiance of the CCP (Communist Party of China) warning,\" he said.\n\n\"Our delegation received a letter from the CCP warning us not to come here. They repeated their false claim that Tibet is part of China since the 13th century but we did not let the CCP intimidate us and we are here today,\" he said at the event organised by the Dharamsala-based Central Tibetan Administration (CTA).\n\nHe added that the Dalai Lama, the people of Tibet and the US know that Tibet is not part of China.\n\nThe US delegation included Mariannette Miller, Gregory Meeks, Nicole Malliotakis, Jim McGovern and Ami Bera.\n\nAt his residence, the Dalai Lama told them that he wanted the people of the world to be happy and peaceful.\n\nReferring to the Tibet policy bill, McCaul said at the later event that the timing of the visit could not be better. The bill also required aggressively challenging the CCP propaganda on Tibet, he added.\n\n\"I presented the Dalai Lama with a wind chime, which will remind him of our support,\" he said.\n\n\"Like many of you, I wish that this meeting was happening in your homeland of Tibet, but 65 years ago you were forced to flee after the Chinese Communist Party annexed Tibet and slaughtered tens of thousands of Tibetan people,\" he said.\n\nThe delegation leader claimed that the CCP was determined to eliminate Tibetan culture and forcibly bring the Tibetan people under its control.\n\nThanks to the kindness of the Indian people, the Tibetans who fled their homeland are able to live freely in this country and practise their religion without fear of persecution.\n\n\"It is still my hope that one day His Holiness the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" McCaul said.\n\nHe said the CCP continued to threaten the freedom of the Tibetan people decades later, and accused China of interfering with the process of finding a successor to the Dalai Lama. {"uri": "8185207548", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:28:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:28:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:26:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/explainer-why-has-a-visit-by-u-s-lawmakers-to-india-upset-china/article_b311e53f-7798-597e-9061-576c5add25c8.html", "title": "Explainer-Why has a visit by U.S. lawmakers to India upset China?", "body": "Michael McCaul, the U.S. Republican chair of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, speaks at the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile at Dharamshala, Himachal Pradesh, India, June 18, 2024. REUTERS/Stringer\n\nBy Krishn Kaushik\n\nNEW DELHI (Reuters) - A delegation of U.S. lawmakers met the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama on Wednesday in India's northern town of Dharamsala.\n\nThe meeting annoyed Beijing, which urged the United States on Tuesday to \"fully recognise the anti-China and separatist nature of the Dalai clique\" and refrain from \"any form of contact with it\".\n\nWHY IS THE DELEGATION IN INDIA?\n\nThe bipartisan seven-member group of American lawmakers is visiting India to meet the Nobel peace laureate, the Dalai Lama.\n\nThe United States has long supported the rights of the Tibetan people to practice their religion and culture, and has accused China of human rights violations in the remote Himalayan region that borders India.\n\nA bipartisan bill passed this month by the U.S. House of Representatives aims seeks to push Beijing to hold talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to secure a negotiated agreement on Tibet and spur China to tackle Tibetan aspirations on historical, cultural, religious and linguistic identity.\n\nAmong the delegation are the two authors of the act, titled 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act' or the Resolve Tibet Act, along with Nancy Pelosi, the former speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives.\n\nThe delegation also met officials of Tibet's government in exile, which functions from India.\n\nWHO IS THE DALAI LAMA?\n\nBorn in 1935 as Lhamo Thondup, the Dalai Lama was identified as the reincarnation of his predecessor at the age of two, and enthroned in 1940 as the 14th Dalai Lama in Lhasa, the Tibetan capital.\n\nBeijing invaded Tibet in 1950, and the Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against its rule, since when he has lived in exile in the Himalayan town of Dharamsala.\n\nHe was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989.\n\nWHY IS THE VISIT CONTROVERSIAL?\n\nIt has riled China at a time when Beijing and Washington are struggling to improve ties, and India's relations with China have also been strained since a military standoff on their Himalayan frontier killed 24 soldiers in 2020.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden is expected to sign the Resolve Tibet Act soon, in a bid to find a resolution for the dispute, although Washington considers the Tibetan Autonomous Region to be a part of China.\n\n\"This visit should highlight the bipartisan support in the U.S. Congress for Tibet to have a say in their own future,\" the chief of the U.S. delegation, and one author of the bill, Michael McCaul, said ahead of his departure from Washington on Friday.\n\nWHAT ARE CHINA'S OBJECTIONS?\n\nChina accuses the Dalai Lama of being a \"splittist\" or a separatist, but he says he wants genuine autonomy for his remote Himalayan homeland.\n\nWhile Beijing has always objected to his meetings with foreign leaders, this has not prevented the Dalai Lama from meeting them, including U.S. presidents, although Biden has not met him yet.\n\nHowever, the most contentious issue is the task of appointing his successor.\n\nWhile Beijing has said it has the right to approve a successor, in a move set to strengthen its control over Tibet, the Dalai Lama says only the Tibetan people can make that call, and his successor could be found in India.\n\n(Reporting by Krishn Kaushik; Editing by Clarence Fernandez)\n\nCLICK {"uri": "8186823026", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:31:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:31:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:30:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/for-contact-with-chinese-govt-dalai-lama-must-thoroughly-correct-political-views-foreign-ministry-13784329.html", "title": "For contact with Chinese govt, Dalai Lama must 'thoroughly correct' political views: Foreign ministry", "body": "The Dalai Lama with former US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other members of the US Congressional delegation at his residence, in Dharamshala. (PTI)\n\nThe Chinese foreign ministry said on Thursday that exiled spiritual leader of Tibetan Buddhism the Dalai Lama must \"thoroughly correct\" his political views as a condition for contact with China's central government to resume.\n\nFormal talks between China and the Dalai Lama, who fled to India in 1959 after a failed Tibetan uprising against Chinese rule, and his representatives have been stalled since 2010.\n\n\"With regard to contact and negotiations between the central government of China and the 14th Dalai Lama, our policy has been consistent and clear,\" said Lin Jian, a spokesman at China's foreign ministry.\n\n\"The key is that the 14th Dalai Lama must fundamentally reflect on and thoroughly correct his political views,\" Lin said at a regular ministry news conference.\n\nThe Dalai Lama stepped down in 2011 as the political leader of the Tibetan government-in-exile, which Beijing does not recognise and views as a violation of China's constitution.\n\nYet China continues to chafe at any interaction he has with officials of other countries, including former US presidents, even though the Dalai Lama says he is not seeking independence for Tibet.\n\nThe 88-year-old, whom China sees as a dangerous separatist in a monk's robes, remains the spiritual leader of the Tibetan people.\n\nUS lawmakers are currently asking President Joe Biden to sign a bill aimed at pressing China to secure a negotiated and peaceful agreement on Tibet.\n\nA group of US lawmakers, who met the Dalai Lama in India on Wednesday, said they would not allow China to influence the choice of his successor.\n\nWhile Washington recognises Tibet as a part of China, the bill appears to question that position, analysts say.\n\nBeijing has rejected the Resolve Tibet Act, saying Tibet is part of China and brooks no interference from external forces.\n\n\"We urge the United States to fully recognise the importance and sensitivity of Tibet-related issues and earnestly respect China's core interests,\" Lin said.\n\n\"We should abide by our commitment on the issue of obstacles, refrain from any form of contact with the Dalai clique, and stop sending wrong messages to the {"uri": "8184634160", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "04:25:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T04:25:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T04:23:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/india/nancy-pelosi-meets-with-dalai-lama-in-dharamsala-despite-chinas-criticism/articleshow/111100976.cms", "title": "Nancy Pelosi meets with Dalai Lama in Dharamsala, despite China's criticism", "body": "A US Congressional delegation, led by Rep. Michael McCaul, R-Texas, chair of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, arrived Tuesday in the Himalayan town of Dharamsala, where the Dalai Lama has lived since the 1960s. The delegation visited the offices of the Tibetan government in exile, which is pushing for autonomy for Tibet within China.A high-level U.S. congressional delegation, including former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., met with the Dalai Lama at his Indian home Wednesday, a visit that was condemned in advance by China's government, which considers the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader a separatist.\n\nThe delegation, led by Rep. Michael McCaul, R-Texas, chair of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, arrived Tuesday in the Himalayan town of Dharamsala, where the Dalai Lama has lived since the 1960s. The delegation visited the offices of the Tibetan government in exile, which is pushing for autonomy for Tibet within China.\n\nThe trip comes days after Congress passed a bill with bipartisan support that urged China to start dialogue with Tibetan leaders to find a solution to the long-standing conflict.\n\nChina's criticism of the visit was immediate and unsurprising. Its leaders consider the government in exile illegal and regard any support for the cause of autonomy for Tibet, which they call Xizang, as interference in internal Chinese matters.\n\n\"We urge the U.S. side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honor the commitments the U.S. has made to China on issues related to Xizang, stop sending the wrong signal to the world,\" the Chinese Embassy in New Delhi said in a statement Tuesday night.\n\nU.S. officials have often met with the Dalai Lama, 88. Pelosi's presence in the delegation, however, brought reminders of her 2022 trip to Taiwan, the self-governing island that China claims as its territory, when she was still speaker of the House.\n\nThat contentious visit, which raised fears within the Biden administration of further deteriorating a frosty relationship with Beijing, led to a sharp response from China, including trade restrictions on Taiwan and military exercises near the island.\n\nThe visit to India also comes as Washington and New Delhi deepen their relationship, motivated in part by the perception of a shared Chinese threat. Jake Sullivan, President Joe Biden's national security adviser, is in New Delhi this week, holding multiple rounds of talks with Indian officials on expanding defense and technology cooperation.\n\nThose extensive discussions, coming weeks after Prime Minister Narendra Modi won a third term in office, indicate how much Washington prioritizes the relationship with India, with U.S. officials increasingly speaking of New Delhi as a counterweight to Beijing.\n\nTenzin Lekshay, a spokesperson for the Central Tibetan Administration, the government in exile, said Tibet's situation should not be seen through \"the lens of increasing rivalry between the U.S. and China,\" but as a reminder of how the Tibetan way of life \"is facing an existential threat\" as China assimilates the region.\n\n\"We do hope that leaders of the free world will stand for the Tibet cause, particularly stressing the Chinese leadership to reinstall the dialogue to resolve the Sino-Tibet conflict,\" Lekshay said.\n\nThis article originally appeared in The New York Times.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8184933817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:30:13", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:30:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:29:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/world/us-delegation-meets-dalai-lama-in-dharamshala-nancy-pelosi-says-china-trying-to-oppress-tibet-2583369", "title": "US delegation meets Dalai Lama in Dharamshala, Nancy Pelosi says China trying to oppress Tibet", "body": "Dharamsala: A US Congressional delegation led by House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaul met Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in Himachal Pradesh's Dharamsala on Tuesday. The group of influential US lawmakers, including said they would not allow China to influence the choice of his successor, comments that may rile up Beijing which calls him a separatist.\n\nThe delegation, which is on a two-day visit to India, comprises former US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Congress members Mariannette Miller, Gregory Meeks, Nicole Malliotakis, Jim McGovern and Ami Bera. The US lawmakers met the Nobel peace laureate at his monastery in the northern town of Dharamsala.\n\nThey indicated that Washington would exert pressure on Beijing to initiate talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to find a solution to the Tibet issue with a bill US President Joe Biden is expected to sign soon.\n\nSpeaking at a public reception after the meeting, former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said the Dalai Lama will live a long time with his \"message of knowledge, and tradition\" while Chinese President Xi Jinping will be gone and won't be remembered for anything.\n\n\"I had told to the President of China during his visit to the Washington DC that you are trying to oppress the Tibet. He said that we should go to the Tibet and see all the improvement that China is making in Tibet. We went, the delegation, to the Potala Palace. They are trying something that we can not let them get away with. This legislation sends the message, the House and the Senate, and the President of the USA Joe Biden is soon going to sign this. People are important for this Bill to be passed,\" she said.\n\n\"Dalai Lama will live long and his legacy will live on forever. But you, the President of China, you will be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything. I know Dalai Lama would not approve when I criticise China. But change is on the way. Faith of Tibetan people in goodness of others is what is going to make all the difference. God bless Tibet and God bless America,\" she added.\n\nThe US has strongly been supporting the Tibetan cause and condemning all oppression and coercion of Tibetans by China. China recently warned of \"resolute measures\" if the Tibet policy bill is signed into law by the US President.\n\nEarlier this month, the US Congress passed a legislation, the Resolve Tibet Act, calling for a peaceful resolution of the dispute over the status and governance of Tibet. It also calls on Beijing to resume dialogue with the Tibetan spiritual leader.\n\nChina objected to the Act and asked Biden not to sign it. \"Anyone or any force who attempts to destabilise Xizang to contain or suppress China will not succeed,\" Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Lin Jian told reporters in Beijing on Tuesday. \"The US should not sign the bill. China will take resolute measures to defend its sovereignty, security and development interests,\" he said. China officially refers to Tibet as Xizang.\n\nThe Dalai Lama has been demanding an autonomy for his remote Himalayan homeland. In its talks with China between 2002 and 2010, the Tibetan side pitched autonomy for all Tibetan areas including Gansu, Qinghai, Sichuan and Yunnan provinces besides the current official Tibet {"uri": "2024-06-394462899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "09:20:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T09:20:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T09:13:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/china-dalai-lama-successor-united-states-tibet-9401504/", "title": "'Won't allow China to influence choice of the Dalai Lama's successor': US lawmakers after meeting Tibetan spiritual leader | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "Beijing, which considers the Dalai Lama a dangerous 'separatist', had said it was seriously concerned about the visit of the US lawmakers to Dharamsala and the Bill.\n\nA United States group of lawmakers, following their visit to the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama on Wednesday, asserted that they would not allow China to influence the choice of his successor.\n\nFormer United States Congress Speaker Nancy Pelosi, addressing a gathering in Himachal Pradesh Wednesday, hailed her meeting with the Dalai Lama at his monastery in Dharamsala.\n\nPelosi was among the seven members of the US Congressional delegation who met the spiritual leader Wednesday. The delegation was led by US House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaul, and comprised Mariannette Miller, Gregory Meeks, Nicole Malliotakis, Jim McGovern, and Ami Bera, besides Pelosi.\n\n\"...His Holiness Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live a long time and his legacy will live forever. But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything. Dalai Lama would not approve of my saying that when I criticize the Chinese government, he says, let's pray for Nancy to rid her of her negative attitudes,\" Pelosi said at an event on Wednesday.\n\n\"I hope he will indulge me today to say that change is on the way. As our colleagues have said hope brings some faith and the faith of the Tibetan people in the goodness of others is what is going to make all the difference...,\" she continued.\n\nSpeaking about the approval by Congress for the legislation, titled 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', or the Resolve Tibet Act, Pelosi said it sent a message to China that Washington is clear in its thinking on the issue of Tibet.\n\n\"This Bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, get ready for that,\" Pelosi was quoted as saying by PTI.\n\n'We will not let that happen': Michael McCaul\n\nMcCaul, meanwhile, at a public reception after the meeting, said, \"It is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" news agency PTI reported.\n\nMoreover, on Beijing's interference into choosing the successor of the Dalai Lama, which has been a widely-debated issue, McCaul said, \"We will not let that happen.\"\n\nDispute over choosing the Dalai Lama's successor\n\nWhile Beijing has continued to stand firm that its officially atheist Communist leaders have the right to approve the successor - as a legacy inherited from China's emperors - the Tibetan tradition holds that the Dalai Lama is reincarnated after his death, and the current leader has said his successor may be found in India, PTI stated.\n\nBeijing, which considers the Dalai Lama a dangerous \"separatist,\" had said it was seriously concerned about the visit of the lawmakers to Dharamsala and the bill. It also urged the lawmakers not to contact the \"Dalai clique,\" PTI report stated.\n\nIn Beijing, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson, Lin Jian, urged Biden not to sign the bipartisan Tibet Policy Bill adopted by both the US Senate and the House of Representatives. According to media reports from Washington, the Bill, which seeks to counter China's narrative about its control over Tibet and promote dialogue between the Chinese government and the Dalai Lama, awaits Biden's signature to make it into a law.\n\nDharamsala has been the seat of power for Tibet's government in exile since the spiritual leader stepped into India six decades ago.", "source": And thinking about the whole world, we are same human being. We all have same right and this world belongs to humanity. We should take care of this world irrespective of what religion or tradition the people of the world should be peaceful, happy, that's our goal.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama has been living in exile at McLeodGanj in Dharamshala ever since he fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet.\n\nMaCaul said that the US aims to take forward the resolution of the Tibetan issue.\n\n\"It is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" he said.\n\nFormer Speaker of House of Representatives and top democrat Nancy Pelosi had earlier visited Dharamshala 2008, attacking China had said \"His Holiness Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live a long time and his legacy will live forever. {"uri": "8184837079", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:21:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:21:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:21:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "http://www.chronicle.lu/category/international-news/50299-us-lawmakers-meet-tibets-dalai-lama-warn-china-on-choice-of-successor", "title": "US Lawmakers Meet Tibet's Dalai Lama, Warn China on Choice of Successor", "body": "DHARAMSALA, India (Reuters) - A group of US lawmakers who met the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in India on Wednesday 19 June 2024 said they would not allow China to influence the choice of his successor, comments expected to anger Beijing which calls him a separatist.\n\nThey also signalled that Washington would pressure Beijing to hold talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to resolve the Tibet issue with a bill President Joe Biden is expected to sign soon.\n\nThe bipartisan group of seven, led by Michael McCaul, a Republican representative from Texas, who also chairs the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, met the Nobel peace laureate at his monastery in the northern town of Dharamsala.\n\n\"It is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" McCaul told a public reception after the meeting.\n\nBeijing has even attempted to insert itself into choosing the successor of the Dalai Lama, he said, but added, \"We will not let that happen.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet. Having suffered from health problems for years, the 88-year-old is set to fly to the United States this week for medical treatment.\n\nThe question of his successor has been a contentious and widely debated issue.\n\nBeijing has said the tradition must continue and its officially atheist Communist leaders have the right to approve the successor, as a legacy inherited from China's emperors.\n\nTibetan tradition holds that the Dalai Lama is reincarnated after his death, and the current leader has said his successor may be found in India.\n\nThe dispute indicates the power and influence attached to the role and the tussle between Beijing and its rivals to control it, analysts say.\n\nThe US group, which includes Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived on Tuesday to a warm reception from school children, Buddhist monks and nuns.\n\nPelosi said that approval by Congress for the legislation, titled the \"Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act\", or the Resolve Tibet Act, sends a message to China that Washington is clear in its thinking on the issue of Tibet.\n\n\"This bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, get ready for that,\" Pelosi said to cheers from hundreds of Tibetans at Wednesday's event.\n\nBeijing, which calls the Dalai Lama a dangerous \"splittist\" or separatist, said it was seriously concerned about the visit of the lawmakers to Dharamsala and the bill.\n\nIt urged the lawmakers not to make contact with what it calls the \"Dalai clique\" and Biden not to sign the bill.\n\nChinese officials chafe at any interactions of the Dalai Lama with officials of other countries, though he has met US officials, including presidents, on previous US visits.\n\nBiden, however, has not met the Dalai {"uri": "8184743903", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "06:09:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T06:09:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T06:08:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://news.abplive.com/news/world/us-congressional-delegation-resolve-tibet-act-nancy-pelosi-reach-dharamshala-visit-dalai-lama-1696625", "title": "US Congress Delegation, Including Nancy Pelosi, In Dharamshala To Meet Dalai Lama", "body": "Former US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi at Kangra Airport. ( Image Source :PTI )\n\nA seven-member US Congressional delegation, including former US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi and led by House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Michael McCaul, arrived at the Dalai Lama Temple in Himachal Pradesh's Dharamshala on Wednesday to meet the Tibetan spiritual leader.\n\nThe delegation arrived in India on Tuesday for a two-day visit, and was received by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at Kangra Airport. Other members of the delegation include Congress members Mariannette Miller, Gregory Meeks, Nicole Malliotakis, Jim McGovern and Ami Bera.\n\nThe visit comes as US President Joe Biden is set to reportedly sign a legislation that aims to press China to resolve the Tibet dispute. Beijing has been critical of both moves, saying Tibet is an internal matter of China that brooks no interference by external forces, Reuters reported.\n\nTalking about the visit, Dolma Gyari, the security minister of the Central Tibetan Administration, the Tibetan government-in-exile, told ANI that the message was clear to China \"that freedom-loving nations in the world, people who promote peace and justice, support Tibet\". She also added that the US support for Tibetan people is a strong message. She stated that it can be seen as \"support for India also\".\n\nMcCaul expressed enthusiasm about the visit and was quoted by PTI as saying, \"We are excited to meet His Holiness the Dalai Lama and to talk about many things, including the bill passed by Congress which basically says that the United States of America stands with the people of Tibet.\"\n\nMcCaul said President Joe Biden would soon sign the 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', also known as the 'Resolve Tibet Act', cleared by the US Congress last week.\n\nAccording to a Reuters report, the bill aims to push Beijing to hold talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to secure a negotiated agreement on Tibet. It also urges China to address the Tibetan people's aspirations regarding their historical, cultural, religious and linguistic identity, the report said.\n\n\"US lawmakers have regularly visited Dharamsala and touted the work of the Dalai Lama to draw global support for linguistic and cultural autonomy in his remote, mountainous homeland,\" the report added. A figure of deep respect among Tibetans, the Dalai Lama is described by China as a separatist. The Central Tibetan Administration and the Dalai Lama say they don't seek independence for Tibet but bat for \"genuine autonomy for all Tibetans living in the three traditional provinces of Tibet within the framework of the People's Republic of China\".\n\nSpeaking to ANI, Tenzin Lekshay, spokesperson of the Tibetan government-in-exile, said the US delegation's visit is a \"jubilant\" moment for them. He said the US delegation and His Holiness Dalai Lama held a high-level meeting.\n\n\"The Resolve Tibet Act, which has already been significantly adopted, is now at the desk of President Biden. So, they are confident that President Biden will soon sign the bill and it will become a law. This is a very important thing for us,\" the spokesperson said.\n\nHe said China is always unhappy when Tibetans do something, adding that China should introspect \"to see that whatever was done over the course of 70 years is not for Tibetans but for China's good\".\n\nLekshay added that they were grateful to the Indian government and the public \"for all they did for the Tibetans\", saying the Tibetan issue concerns India as well. \"So, I think Indian people should also be aware of the Tibetan issue,\" he said.\n\nThe US delegation's visit has come at a time when the US and China have sought to stabilise their rocky relations, the Reuters report noted. {"uri": "8184928872", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:26:47", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:26:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:26:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/explainers/us-american-lawmakers-nancy-pelosi-visit-dalai-lama-in-india-stirs-tensions-with-beijing-a-look-at-the-china-tibet-history-13783875.html", "title": "US lawmakers' visit to Dalai Lama stirs tensions with Beijing. A look at the fraught China-Tibet history", "body": "Tibetans holding the US, Indian and Tibetan flags wait to welcome a bipartisan US congressional delegation, led by Republican Representative Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi at the Kangra airport in Kangra, Himachal Pradesh, 18 June, 2024. Reuters\n\nA bipartisan delegation of lawmakers from the United States, led by Republican Representative Michael McCaul and including Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived in the town of Dharamsala in Himachal Pradesh on Tuesday (18 June) to meet with the Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama.\n\nThis visit is part of an ongoing effort to push China to resolve the long-standing Tibet dispute. The delegation's visit has sparked significant backlash from Beijing, coming at a time when the US and China are attempting to stabilise their rocky relationship.\n\nThe US delegation's visit aims to discuss the recently passed 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act,' commonly known as the Resolve Tibet Act. The bill urges Beijing to engage in dialogue with Tibetan leaders, a process that has been stalled since 2010, to negotiate an agreement on Tibet's future. The bill is now awaiting US President Joe Biden's signature.\n\n\"We are very excited to see His Holiness tomorrow to talk about many things, including the bill we just passed out of Congress that basically says the United States of America stands with the people of Tibet,\" McCaul had said. He confirmed that Biden would soon sign the bill into law.\n\nUpon their arrival at Kangra airport, the delegation was greeted by crowds of Tibetans, including school children holding banners and dozens of monks and nuns in maroon robes, who cheered as the lawmakers made their way to meet the Dalai Lama.\n\nBeijing's reaction to the US visit\n\nChina has expressed serious concern about the visit of the US lawmakers to Dharamsala and the potential signing of the Resolve Tibet Act by Biden. Lin Jian, a spokesperson for the Chinese foreign ministry, stated, \"We urge the US to fully recognise the anti-China and separatist nature of the Dalai clique, abide by its commitments on Tibet-related issues, refrain from any form of contact with it, and stop sending erroneous messages.\"\n\nHe stated that Tibet's affairs are purely internal matters for China and warned that Beijing would take \"resolute and forceful measures\" to safeguard its sovereignty, security, and development interests.\n\nThe Dalai Lama, who fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet, is viewed by Beijing as a dangerous separatist. Chinese officials have long been irked by his interactions with foreign officials, and the recent visit by the US delegation has further fueled their ire.\n\n\"It's known by all that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure, but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities under the cloak of religion,\" Lin added, urging the US side to \"have no contact with the Dalai group in any form, and stop sending the wrong signal to the world.\"\n\nDespite Beijing's protests, the Dalai Lama denies being a separatist and insists that he only advocates for substantial autonomy and the protection of Tibet's native Buddhist culture under Chinese rule.\n\nHistorical context of China-Tibet relations\n\nThe conflict over Tibet's status within China is deeply rooted in historical claims and political developments. China's motivations for annexing Tibet in 1950 were both ideological and pragmatic.\n\nThe Chinese Communist Party (CCP) aimed to shore up China's southwestern border and access Tibet's plentiful natural resources. Ideologically, the CCP viewed Tibet as a feudal-theocracy that needed \"liberation\" and believed that Tibet had always been a part of China, making its incorporation a historical necessity.\n\nHowever, Tibet's history is complex and distinct. Prior to the 1950 invasion, Tibet had existed independently of Chinese control, with its own unique culture, language, and religion. Even after the Qing dynasty established suzerainty over Tibet in 1720, Tibetans remained largely free of direct Chinese interference. Following the end of Qing rule in 1911, Tibet functioned as a de facto independent state until the Chinese invasion.\n\nThe People's Liberation Army (PLA) crossed the Jinsha (Yangtze) River and entered Tibet on 7 October, 1950. By 19 October, they had captured Chamdo, neutralising the Tibetan garrison there. Over 3,000 Tibetans were made prisoners, and at least 180 died in the fighting. The defeat led to the signing of the Seventeen Point Agreement in May 1951, which effectively subordinated Tibet to China while promising to maintain Tibetan autonomy, culture, and religion.\n\nDespite these assurances, Chinese interference in Tibetan affairs grew, leading to widespread unrest. By 1959, frustration with Chinese policies led to a revolt in Lhasa.\n\nAlso Read: Tibetan culture, livelihoods are being damned in Xi Jinping's China\n\nFearing arrest by the Chinese, the Dalai Lama fled to India on 23 March, 1959, repudiating the Seventeen Point Agreement and proclaiming himself Tibet's legitimate representative. Since then, China's control over Tibet has been absolute, with severe crackdowns on dissent and efforts to assimilate Tibetans into Chinese culture.\n\nThe role of the Dalai Lama\n\nThe Dalai Lama, Tenzin Gyatso, is revered by Tibetans worldwide as their spiritual leader. Since his exile in India, he has lobbied for Tibetan self-rule and substantial autonomy under Chinese sovereignty. He received the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989 for his efforts to resolve the Tibet issue peacefully.\n\nThe Dalai Lama has a history of engaging with US officials. He has met with every American president from Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama, except for Donald Trump, and is yet to meet Joe Biden. These meetings have often led to stern condemnation from China, which views them as undermining its sovereignty and supporting Tibetan independence.\n\nThe recent visit by US lawmakers to Dharamsala is seen by China as part of a broader strategy by Washington to counter Beijing's influence. This perception is compounded by the strengthening of US-India relations, with both countries viewing each other as counterweights to China's rising power.\n\nChina's tightening grip on Tibet\n\nSince the 1959 uprising, China has tightened its grip on Tibet, implementing policies aimed at assimilating Tibetans and eradicating dissent. Beijing has facilitated the influx of Han Chinese into Tibet, changing its demographic and cultural landscape. The Chinese government has also installed its own people in key religious positions, further eroding Tibetan autonomy.\n\nIn recent years, China has also sought to control the process of selecting the Dalai Lama's successor. Beijing insists that it has the right to approve the next Dalai Lama, a claim rooted in its historical role of endorsing Tibetan Buddhist leaders.\n\nThe Dalai Lama, however, has stated that his successor may be found outside Tibet, possibly in India, a move that Beijing strongly opposes.\n\nWhat the future may hold\n\nThe ongoing tension between China and Tibet remains a significant issue in international politics. The US and other countries continue to express support for Tibetan autonomy and cultural preservation. The Resolve Tibet Act, if signed into law by Biden, will further solidify US support for the Tibetan cause and pressure China to engage in dialogue.\n\nThe Dalai Lama's health remains a concern as he approaches his 89th birthday. He is expected to travel to the US for medical treatment, but it is unclear if he will meet with any officials during his visit. The question of his successor looms large, with the potential to further escalate tensions between China and the Tibetan exile community.\n\nAlso Read: With China willing to discuss 'Dalai Lama's future', Tibetan fate hangs in balance\n\nThe historical context of China-Tibet relations, coupled with recent developments, has only underlined the complexity and sensitivity of this issue. The US, along with India continues to be focused on finding a peaceful resolution that respects the rights and aspirations of the Tibetan people.", "source": {"uri": "firstpost.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8186515116", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "07:19:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T07:19:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T07:16:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2752430/", "title": "You will be gone... Nancy Pelosis warns Xi Jinping on the Tibet issue - ExBulletin", "body": "Former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, part of a bipartisan US delegation that met with the Dalai Lama on Wednesday, issued a stern warning to Chinese President Xi Jinping. She said that although the Tibetan spiritual leader's legacy would live on forever, the Chinese president would disappear in a few years.\n\nNews agency ANI quoted Pelosi, who is on a two-day visit to India, as saying: \"His Holiness the Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love , will live long and his legacy will live forever. But you, the president of China, will be gone and no one will give you credit for anything.\n\nAdding that the Dalai Lama would not approve of his comments against Xi Jinping, Pelosi said: \"When I criticize the Chinese government, he (the Dalai Lama) says: let's pray that Nancy rids her of her negative attitudes.\" \"\n\nPelosi made the remarks during the public felicitation program at Tsuglagkhang Complex in Dharamshala.\n\nArriving in India on Tuesday, the bipartisan Congressional delegation was received by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at the Kangra airport in Himachal Pradesh.\n\nLast week, the US Congress passed a bill aimed at challenging China's assertion of historic control over Tibet and encouraging Beijing to resume dialogue with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully address their differences regarding the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nAfter the US House of Representatives passed the \"Promoting a Resolution of the Tibet-China Dispute Act\", also known as the \"Tibet Resolution Act\", the bill is now waiting signed by US President Joe Biden to become law.\n\nRegarding the bill, ANI quoted Pelosi as saying: \"You heard our colleagues talk about this legislation that passed last week. We have been fighting this for a long time and in the spirituality of His Holiness, through maneuvering within Congress, we have made progress.\"\n\n\"But it's different now with the passage of this bill (Resolve Tibet Act) because this bill is a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Pelosi added.\n\n\"They (the Chinese government) are trying to erase the culture (of Tibet) by reducing the use of language. They are trying something that we cannot allow them to get away with. I will be kind to the Chinese people , I do not do it\". I don't know they're planning this, but we know the Chinese government is, and we know they have to get the message,\" the former speaker of the US House of Representatives said, adding: \"This legislation sends the message to the House and Senate and will soon be signed by Joe Biden, the President of the United States...\"\n\nOn Tuesday, Michael McCaul, Republican Chairman of the US House of Representatives Committee on Foreign Affairs and a member of the bipartisan US delegation, confirmed President Biden's intention to sign the Resolve Tibet Act.\n\nGregory Meeks, the US representative leading the delegation's visit to India, responded strongly to Beijing's criticism of their visit, saying the US would respect what is fair and just.\n\n\"China can express its displeasure if it wants. We will stand up for what is right,\" Meeks said, adding: \"What is right is to ensure that Tibetans enjoy freedom. They can return to their native country and they are able to keep their culture and their history... That's what's important....\"\n\nOn Tuesday, Beijing expressed serious concerns about the visit and urged the United States to \"fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai Lama group.\"\n\nHe also warned the United States against signing the bill, saying \"China will take resolute measures to firmly defend its sovereignty, security and development interests.\"\n\nMcCaul said the delegation, including Pelosi, also received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party warning them against coming to Dharamshala.\n\n\"They repeated their false claim that Tibet has been part of China since the 13th century, but we did not allow ourselves to be intimidated by the CCP because we are here today. The Dalai Lama knows this is not true, that Tibet is part of China and the Tibetan people know this is not true. The United States too knows that this is not true,\" he said, adding: \"That is why we are here today, in defiance of this warning. \"", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8185511725", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "14:50:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T14:50:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T14:48:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/nancy-pelosi-jabs-xi-jinping-dalai-lamas-legacy-will-live-youll-be-gone-2555400-2024-06-19", "title": "Nancy Pelosi jabs Xi Jinping: 'Dalai Lama's legacy will live, you'll be gone'", "body": "A delegation of US lawmakers, including former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, met with the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, on Wednesday in Himachal Pradesh's Dharamshala. Pelosi, in her remarks, targeted China's President Xi Jinping while praising the Dalai Lama's enduring legacy.\n\n\"...His Holiness Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live a long time and his legacy will live forever. But you, the President of China, you'll be gone and nobody will give you credit for anything,\" Nancy Pelosi said.\n\nShe added, \"Dalai Lama would not approve of my saying that when I criticise the Chinese government, he says, let's pray for Nancy to rid her of her negative attitudes. I hope he will indulge me today to say that change is on the way.\"\n\nThe meeting of US lawmakers with the Dalai Lama, which underscores Washington's support for Tibetan rights, has drawn sharp criticism from Beijing.\n\nThe visit has heightened tensions between the US and China, already strained due to various geopolitical issues. China, which considers the Dalai Lama a separatist, has vehemently opposed the meeting.\n\nThe seven-member US delegation is visiting India in the wake of the recently passed \"Resolve Tibet Act\" by the US House of Representatives, which seeks to pressure Beijing into resuming dialogue with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, and address Tibetan aspirations for historical, cultural, religious, and linguistic identity.\n\nThe Dalai Lama, born Lhamo Thondup in 1935, was recognised as the reincarnation of his predecessor at the age of two and was enthroned in 1940. Following a failed uprising against Chinese rule in 1959, he fled to India, where he has lived in exile in Dharamsala. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 1989.\n\nThe issue of the Dalai Lama's successor remains contentious. Beijing insists on its right to approve the next Dalai Lama, a move seen as an attempt to tighten its control over Tibet. However, the Dalai Lama maintains that the choice lies solely with the Tibetan people and has suggested that his successor could be found in India.\n\nPrior to the US lawmakers' meeting with the Dalai Lama, a Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson urged the US to \"fully recognise the anti-China and separatist nature of the Dalai clique\" and to refrain from \"any form of contact with it.\"", {"uri": "8185272055", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:07:58", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:07:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:07:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.voanews.com/a/us-lawmakers-meet-dalai-lama-as-china-slams-visit-/7661821.html", "title": "US lawmakers meet Dalai Lama as China slams visit", "body": "A group of U.S. lawmakers met the Dalai Lama in India's northern town of Dharamshala Wednesday, amid cheers from Tibetans in exile and an angry reaction from China, which calls the Tibetan spiritual leader a separatist and a splittist.\n\nThe visit follows the passage last week of a bill by the U.S. Congress that seeks to encourage dialogue between Beijing and Tibetan leaders in exile, who have been seeking more autonomy for Tibet. Talks with the Dalai Lama's representatives and China stalled in 2010.\n\n\"This bill is a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of the freedom of Tibet,\" Nancy Pelosi, former House Speaker, said to cheers from hundreds of Tibetans whom the lawmakers addressed at a public ceremony after meeting the Dalai Lama at his residence.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden is expected to soon sign the legislation called \"Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act,\" also referred to as the Resolve Tibet Act.\n\nIn Dharamshala, where the Tibetan government in exile is based, the visit of the U.S. lawmakers brought hope. \"It is a jubilant moment for all Tibetans. We are all overjoyed. The visit is very significant because it comes soon after the passage of the bill which we hope will soon be passed into law,\" Tenzin Lekshay, spokesperson for the Central Tibetan Administration, told VOA.\n\nCongressman Michael McCaul, who led the seven-member visiting delegation, said the bill reaffirms American support for what he referred to as the Tibetan right to self- determination. He said that their delegation had received a letter from the Chinese Communist Party, warning them not to visit.\n\nBeijing said the U.S. should not sign into law the bill passed by Congress. \"China will take resolute measures to firmly defend its sovereignty, security and development interests,\" Chinese foreign ministry spokesman, Lin Jian said on Tuesday, as the lawmakers arrived in the Indian town.\n\nThe Chinese embassy in New Delhi reiterated Beijing's concerns. \"We urge the U.S. side to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group, honor the commitments the U.S. has made to China on issues related to Xizang, stop sending the wrong signal to the world,\" it said in a statement Tuesday night. Xizang is China's name for Tibet.\n\nIn his remarks to Tibetans, McCaul said it is important that China not influence the choice of the Dalai Lama's successor. \"Beijing has even attempted to insert itself into choosing the successor of the Dalai Lama,\" he said. \"We will not let that happen.\"\n\nThe issue is contentious. China says it has the right to approve the spiritual leader's successor while according to Tibetan tradition, the Dalai Lama is reincarnated after his death. The Dalai Lama has said his successor is likely to be found in India but Tibetans in exile fear China will try to designate a person to be the successor, in an effort to bolster control over Tibet.\n\nMeanwhile, Tibetan spokesman Lekshay said China needs to come forward to reinstate a dialogue with exiled Tibetan leaders. \"It is a time for introspection for China to see what is going wrong, particularly with the Tibet issue which has been a longstanding conflict. China needs to be more positive.\"\n\nBeijing does not recognize the exiled administration. A formal dialogue process between the Dalai Lama's representatives and the Chinese government ended in 2010 after it failed to produce a concrete outcome.\n\nPointing out that they are asking for autonomy within China and not independence, Lekshay said the Tibetan administration in exile did not represent a separatist movement.\n\nTibetans in exile say they fear that their culture, language and identity is under threat due to Chinese assimilation of the region.\n\nThe Dalai Lama, who fled to India in 1959, has been instrumental in putting the Tibetan cause in the global spotlight but in recent years some Tibetan activists have expressed concerns that the Tibet cause is not getting appropriate attention in Western capitals.\n\nThe Himalayan town of Dharamshala has been the Dalai Lama's home since he fled Tibet over six decades ago following a failed uprising against Chinese rule.", "source": {"uri": "voanews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "VOA Voice of America"}, {"uri": "8185345097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:57:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:57:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:56:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2751287/", "title": "Former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi meets Dalai Lama, criticizes Xi Jinping Firstpost - ExBulletin", "body": "The United States has historically defended the freedom of the Tibetan people to exercise their religion and culture and has accused China of violating those rights in the remote Himalayan territory that shares a border with India.\n\nLearn more\n\nAs part of a bipartisan team of American politicians visiting India, former Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi met the Dalai Lama on Wednesday. Hours later, she launched a scathing criticism of China and lambasted Chinese President Xi Jinping.\n\n\"His Holiness the Dalai Lama will live long and his legacy will live forever, but you, the president, will be gone and no one will give you credit for anything. The Dalai Lama would not approve of me saying that I criticize the Chinese government. It said, \"Let's pray that Nancy will rid her of her negative attitudes. \" But I hope that it will allow me today to say that change is underway. As our colleagues have said, hope brings some faith and the faith of the Tibetan people, in the goodness of others, is going to make all the difference,\" Pelosi told a gathering of enthusiastic Tibetans.\n\nAdditionally, she said bipartisan support for the Resolve Tibet Act conveys to China Washington's clear position on the issue.\n\n\"This bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, prepare for this,\" she said.\n\nWith President Joe Biden's signature, the act will force China to reopen conversations with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders, suspended for 14 years.\n\nUnlike every American president since George HW Bush, Biden has never had a meeting with the Dalai Lama.\n\nOnce signed, the Resolve Tibet Act will serve as a powerful declaration of the United States of America's commitment to the people of Tibet, according to Tibetan leaders, particularly the Central Tibetan Administration, or CTA.\n\nThe United States has historically defended the freedom of the Tibetan people to exercise their religion and culture and has accused China of violating those rights in the remote Himalayan territory that shares a border with India.\n\nHowever, what is confusing is that the United States also considers the Tibet Autonomous Region to be a part of China.\n\nPelosi's surprising attack not only strengthens India's position against China, but also highlights Washington's intention to prevent Beijing from interfering in the nomination of the next Dalai Lama and coincides with the signing by US President Joe Biden of a law forcing Beijing to resolve the Tibet problem.\n\nThe Dalai Lama, who turns 89 next month, is usually reincarnated and he has said his successor could be found in India. But in keeping with historical tradition, China maintains that the next Dalai Lama will be appointed by officially atheist communist officials.\n\nCongressman Gregory Meeks (D-NY) led the US team that arrived in India on Tuesday. At Kangra airport in Himachal Pradesh, they were greeted by Tibetan officials, Buddhist monks and nuns and schoolchildren. This visit precedes that of the Dalai Lama to receive medical treatment for a knee illness.\n\nTheir visit is notable because it coincides with efforts by Beijing and Washington to strengthen ties between these two military and economic superpowers. China has already expressed its dissatisfaction.\n\nBeijing said it was \"seriously concerned\" about the US delegation's visit and the law Biden is expected to sign, viewing the Nobel Peace Prize {"uri": "8184864450", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:43:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:43:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:41:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/india/us-delegation-meets-dalai-lama-in-himachal-pradesh-invites-chinas-ire-what-nancy-pelosi-said/articleshow/111105125.cms", "title": "US delegation meets Dalai Lama in Himachal Pradesh, invites China's ire: What Nancy Pelosi said | India News - Times of India", "body": "NEW DELHI: A US delegation, led by former US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Republican chair of the US House foreign affairs committee Michael McCaul met Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama in Dharamshala. After the meeting, Pelosi recounted her previous visit to Tibet, where she witnessed the Chinese government's efforts to erase Tibetan culture by suppressing the use of the Tibetan language.\n\nShe highlighted the importance of the recently passed legislation, the 'Resolve Tibet Act', which sends a clear message to the Chinese government about the United States' stance on the issue.\n\nFormer US House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said after meeting Dalai Lama, \"There was a visit of the President of China to Washington, DC and I said to him, we are objecting to what you are doing to the culture of Tibet. He said, you know what you're talking about, you should go there and see for yourself all the improvements that China is making in Tibet. I said, thank you because I've been trying for 25 years to get a visa to go to Tibet. So we went there with our delegation. We went to the Potala Palace. We saw the room where His Holiness grew up.\"\n\n\"They are trying to erase the culture by reducing the use of the language. They are trying something that we cannot let them get away with. I'll be gracious to the Chinese people, I don't know that they're up to this, but we do know that the Chinese government is, and we do know that they must get the message. This legislation sends the message, the House and the Senate and soon to be signed by Joe Biden, the president of the United States.\", she further added.\n\nDolma Tsering Teykhang, deputy speaker of the Tibetan Parliament-in-Exile, said that the visit of the US lawmakers demonstrates that \"Tibet is not alone.\" She highlighted that the delegation's presence sends a message of support for human rights and freedom, not only for Tibet but for anyone aspiring to these values. Teykhang also noted that China is \"annoyed\" with anyone who supports Tibet, but the representatives and senators are there to support a just cause.\n\nEarlier this week, the US Congress passed the 'Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act', also known as the 'Resolve Tibet Act', which urges China to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet. The legislation rejects Beijing's stance that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and calls for an end to the propagation of disinformation about Tibetan history, people, and institutions.\n\nUpon arrival in Dharamshala, Pelosi expressed her excitement about being there, while McCaul affirmed President Biden's intention to sign the 'Resolve Tibet Act'. The US Representative highlighted the significance of the bill passed by Congress and expressed enthusiasm about the upcoming meeting with the Dalai Lama.\n\nChina, however, expressed grave concern over the US delegation's visit to Dharamshala. Chinese foreign ministry spokesperson Lin Jian urged the US to recognize the \"anti-China separatist nature\" of the Dalai Group and to refrain from sending the wrong signal to the world. China maintains that the 14th Dalai Lama is not a pure religious figure but a political exile engaged in anti-China separatist activities.\n\nThe TOI News Desk comprises a dedicated and tireless team of journalists who operate around the clock to deliver the most current and comprehensive news and updates to the readers of The Times of India worldwide. With an unwavering commitment to excellence in journalism, our team is at the forefront of gathering, verifying, and presenting breaking news, in-depth analysis, and insightful reports on a wide range of topics. The TOI News Desk is your trusted source for staying informed and connected to the ever-evolving global landscape, ensuring that our readers are equipped with the latest developments that matter {"uri": "8184842030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "07:26:34", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T07:26:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T07:24:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/politics/us-lawmakers-meet-tibets-dalai-lama-warn-china-c-15075749", "title": "US lawmakers meet Tibet's Dalai Lama, warn China", "body": "A group of US lawmakers who met the exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama in India say they will not allow China to influence the choice of his successor, comments expected to anger Beijing, which calls him a separatist.\n\nThey also signalled that Washington would pressure Beijing to hold talks with Tibetan leaders, stalled since 2010, to resolve the Tibet issue with a bill President Joe Biden is expected to sign soon.\n\nThe bipartisan group of seven, led by Michael McCaul, a Republican representative from Texas, who also chairs the House committee on foreign affairs, met the Nobel peace laureate at his monastery in the northern town of Dharamsala.\n\n\"It is still my hope that one day the Dalai Lama and his people will return to Tibet in peace,\" McCaul told a public reception on Wednesday.\n\nBeijing had even attempted to insert itself into choosing the successor of the Dalai Lama, he said, but added, \"We will not let that happen.\"\n\nThe Dalai Lama fled to India in 1959 after a failed uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet.\n\nAfter years of health problems, the 88-year-old will fly to the United States this week for medical treatment.\n\nThe question of his successor has been a contentious issue.\n\nBeijing has said the tradition must continue and its officially atheist Communist leaders have the right to approve the successor, as a legacy inherited from China's emperors.\n\nTibetan tradition holds that the Dalai Lama is reincarnated after his death, and the current leader has said his successor might be found in India.\n\nThe US group, which includes Democratic former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, arrived on Tuesday to a warm reception from schoolchildren, Buddhist monks and nuns.\n\nPelosi said approval by Congress for the legislation sent a message to China that Washington was clear about Tibet.\n\n\"This bill says to the Chinese government: things have changed now, get ready for that,\" Pelosi said to cheers from hundreds of Tibetans at Wednesday's event.\n\nBeijing, which calls the Dalai Lama a dangerous \"splittist\" or separatist, said it was seriously concerned about the lawmakers' visit and the bill.\n\nIt urged them not to make contact with the \"Dalai clique\" and Biden not to sign the bill.\n\nChinese officials chafe at any interactions of the Dalai Lama with officials of other countries, though he has met US officials, {"uri": "8185263214", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:04:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:04:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:02:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2751255/", "title": "Nancy Peolsi meets the Dalai Lama: The Dalai Lama's legacy will live forever, you will be gone: Nancy Pelosi attacks Chinese President Xi Jinping - ExBulletin", "body": "Pelosi, who is on a two-day visit to India, said \"no one will credit Xi for anything.\"\n\n\"His Holiness the Dalai Lama, with his message of knowledge, tradition, compassion, purity of soul and love, will live long and his legacy will live forever. But you, the President of China, will be gone and no one will give credit for anything,\" the former Speaker of the United States House of Representatives said.\n\nPelosi said the Dalai Lama would not approve of his comments against the Chinese. \"When I criticize the Chinese government, he said, let's pray that Nancy rids it of its negative attitudes,\" Pelosi said during the public felicitation program at the Tsuglagkhang complex in Dharamshala.\n\nThe bipartisan Congressional delegation arrived in India on Tuesday and was received the same day by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at the Kangra airport in Himachal Pradesh.\n\nLast week, the US Congress passed a bill urging Beijing to reconnect with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nThe US House of Representatives has passed the \"Promoting a Resolution of the Tibet-China Dispute\" bill, also known as the \"Resolve Tibet Act\", and it must now be signed by President Joe Biden to become a law, Radio Free Asia reported. .\n\n\"You heard our colleagues talk about this legislation that passed last week. We have been fighting this for a long time and in the spirituality of His Holiness, through the maneuvering within Congress, we have made progress. But it is different now with the passage of this bill (Resolve Tibet Act) because this bill is a message to the Chinese government that we have clarity in our thinking and our understanding of this issue of freedom. Tibet,\" Pelosi said.\n\nPelosi further recalled the Chinese president's visit to Washington, D.C., where she told him that the United States \"objects\" to what China is doing to Tibet's culture.\n\nIn response, Xi said: \"You know what you are talking about, you should go there and see for yourself all the improvements that China is making in Tibet,\" Pelosi recalled.\n\n\"They are trying to erase the culture by reducing the use of language. They are trying something that we cannot allow them to get away with. I will be kind to the Chinese people, I don't know if they are able to do it but we know the Chinese government is, and we know they need to get the message. This bill sends the message to the House and the Senate and will soon be signed by Joe Biden, the president. of the United States..\" added the former Speaker of the United States House of Representatives.\n\nUS Congressman Gregory Meeks, who is also leading the US delegation's visit to India, sharply responded to Beijing's criticism of his visit and said the US would stand up for what is right.\n\n\"China can express its dissatisfaction if it wishes. We will stand up for what is right. What is right is to ensure that Tibetans enjoy freedom. They can return to their homeland and maintain their culture and history...That's what's important,\" he said.\n\nSikyong Penpa Tsering of the Central Tibetan Administration said that \"no one can really make China happy.\"\n\n\"The meeting lasted about an hour. His Holiness (the Dalai Lama) spoke about the general interest of society... He thanked the members of the US Congress for passing the legislation,\" Penpa Tsering told about the meeting of the American delegation. Dharamshala.\n\nHe added: \"Who can make China happy? They need to look at the reality and the situation and understand it from a better perspective. \"\n\nThe US legislation notably rejects Beijing's position that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and urges China to \"stop spreading disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people and Tibetan institutions, including including that of the Dalai Lama.\n\nHe also urged China to begin negotiations with the Dalai Lama, who is Tibet's spiritual leader, and other Tibetan leaders over how Tibet is governed. No formal negotiations between the two parties have taken place since 2010.\n\nSeparately, China said on Tuesday that Beijing was \"gravely concerned\" by the US delegation's visit to Dharamshala.\n\nAt a regular press conference yesterday, Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Lin Jian called on the United States to fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai {"uri": "8184406075", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "23:41:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T23:41:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T23:40:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.voanews.com/a/us-lawmakers-meet-with-tibetan-parliament-and-dalai-lama/7661190.html", "title": "US lawmakers meet with Tibetan Parliament and Dalai Lama", "body": "A bipartisan group of U.S. lawmakers led by Congressman Michael McCaul and former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi arrived Tuesday in Dharamshala, India, to visit the Tibetan Parliament in Exile -- also known as the Central Tibetan Administration or CTA -- and meet with the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama.\n\n\"It is an honor to be standing in your temple of democracy,\" McCaul said at the Kangra Airport, noting the group would be meeting Wednesday with the Dalai Lama.\n\n\"It's very exciting to be here,\" Pelosi said, emphasizing the delegation's focus is to advocate for the Resolve Tibet Act and visit the Dalai Lama.\n\nCrowds of Tibetans gathered at the airport to meet the visiting delegation. The group included schoolchildren with banners and dozens of monks and nuns.\n\nBill encourages conversation\n\nThe visit comes with expectations that U.S. President Joe Biden soon will sign legislation called \"Promoting a Resolution to the Tibet-China Dispute Act,\" also called the Resolve Tibet Act, was passed by the U.S. Congress last week.\n\nThe bill seeks to encourage Beijing to speak with Tibetan leaders, a process that has been stalled since 2010. The goal of discussions would be to develop a negotiated agreement on Tibet that considers the Tibetan people's views on their cultural and historical identity.\n\n\"Over the last two years, the Resolve Tibet Bill was passed ... and it is now on the desk of President Biden, so that will be a game changer,\" said Tenzin Lekshay, spokesperson of the CTA.\n\nChina pushes back on visit\n\nThe U.S. congressional visit and possible signing of the bill received pushback from China, who sees the Dalai Lama as separatist.\n\n\"We ... urge the U.S. to fully recognize the anti-China and separatist nature of the Dalai clique, abide by its commitments on Tibet-related issues, refrain from any form of contact with it, and stop sending erroneous messages,\" foreign ministry spokesperson Lin Jian said on Tuesday.\n\n\"We urge the U.S. side to honor its commitment of recognizing Tibet as part of China and not supporting Tibetan independence, and not to sign the above-mentioned bill,\" he also said during a regular briefing.\n\nThe Dalai Lama fled to India after an unsuccessful 1959 uprising against Chinese rule in Tibet. The Dalai Lama has met U.S. officials and presidents during visits to the country but is yet to meet Biden as president.\n\nSome information from Reuters was used in this report.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8185962631", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "21:19:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T21:19:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T21:16:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/jaishankar-meets-us-congressional-delegation-appreciates-their-support-for-strategic-partnership/2138847/", "title": "Jaishankar meets US Congressional delegation, appreciates their support for strategic partnership", "body": "The US Congressional delegation includes former US House of Representatives Speaker Nancy Pelosi, US Representatives - Gregory Meeks, Mariannette Miller-Meeks, Nicole Malliotakis, Ami Bera and Jim McGovern.\n\nIn a post on X, Jaishankar stated, \"Pleasure to meet with the bipartisan US Congressional delegation led by @RepMcCaul. Thank @SpeakerPelosi, @RepGregoryMeeks, @RepMMM, @NMalliotakis, @RepBera and @RepMcGovern for joining. Appreciate their strong and continued support for the strategic partnership.\"\n\nThe US Congressional delegation, which arrived in India on Tuesday, was received by officials of the Central Tibetan Administration at Himachal Pradesh's Kangra Airport. Upon arrival, the US lawmakers headed to Dharamshala to meet Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama.\n\nOn Wednesday, the high-level US Congressional delegation, led by US Congressman Michael McCaul, met Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama at his residence in Dharamshala.\n\nBefore meeting the Dalai Lama, the US delegates attended a public felicitation programme at the main Tibetan temple. The disciples of the Dalai Lama were also seen in the temple complex this morning. Children performed and displayed Tibetan culture at the felicitation ceremony in the courtyard of the Tsuglagkhang Complex in Dharamshala.\n\nDuring their meeting at his residence in Dharamshala today, McCaul presented Dalai Lama with a framed copy of The Resolve Tibet Act, a bipartisan bill passed by the US Congress to enhance US support for Tibet.\n\nLast week, the US Congress passed a bill urging Beijing to re-engage with the Dalai Lama and other Tibetan leaders to peacefully resolve their dispute over the status and governance of Tibet.\n\nThe legislation rejects Beijing's stance that Tibet has been part of China since ancient times and urges China to \"cease its propagation of disinformation about the history of Tibet, the Tibetan people, and Tibetan institutions, including that of the Dalai Lama,\" Radio Free Asia reported.\n\nThe Dalai Lama presented Buddha Statue to Pelosi at the end of the meeting with the US Congressional delegation, the office of the Dalai Lama said.\n\nThe members of the US Congressional delegation also posed for a group photo with the Tibetan spiritual leader after their meeting. {"uri": "8185397146", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "13:30:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T13:30:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T13:29:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.rt.com/india/599566-nancy-pelosis-meeting-with-dalai/", "title": "Nancy Pelosi's meeting with Dalai Lama in India irks China  --  RT India", "body": "A US delegation's visit to Dharamsala, a town in the Indian state of Himachal Pradesh, to meet the Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, on Tuesday triggered an angry response from Beijing.\n\nThe bipartisan delegation, led by former House Speaker and senior Democratic Party leader Nancy Pelosi, highlighted its support for Tibetan autonomy, which Beijing views as a threat to its sovereignty.\n\nThe Dalai Lama, the spiritual leader of the Tibetan government in exile, which is pushing for Tibet to be granted autonomy within China, has lived in India since the 1960s. Beijing considers the government-in-exile illegal and regards any support for the cause of Tibetan autonomy to be interference in its internal matters.\n\nChinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Lin Jian on Tuesday said Beijing has \"strong concerns\" over the trip and has asked the US to \"see clearly the anti-China separatism nature\" of the Dalai Lama and his followers. The Chinese Embassy in New Delhi also issued a message, asking the US to \"fully recognize the anti-China separatist nature of the Dalai group\" and \"honor the commitments the US has made to China on issues related to Xizang.\"\n\nDespite China's protest, the delegation visited the Dalai Lama's residence in McLeod Ganj, Himachal Pradesh on Wednesday.\n\nRepublican Michael McCaul, chair of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, who was part of the delegation, told media outlets that US President Joe Biden would soon sign a bill that aims to pressure China to resolve the Tibet dispute, according to The Hindustan Times.\n\nA day earlier, McCaul told media that the delegation would discuss \"many things,\" including the bill passed by the US Congress earlier this month calling on Beijing to resume dialogue with the Dalai Lama. The bipartisan legislation called 'The Resolve Tibet Act' aims to \"enhance US support\" for Tibet and \"promote dialogue\" between China and the Dalai Lama toward a \"peaceful resolution of the long-standing dispute.\"\n\nDuring the meeting on Wednesday, Pelosi lashed out at Chinese leader Xi Jinping, saying \"You, the president of China (Xi Jinping), you'll be gone and no one will give you credit for anything.\" She contrasted Xi's legacy with the Dalai Lama's, asserting that the latter's will \"live forever.\"\n\nPelosi had also visited India in 2017 to meet the Dalai Lama, prompting a similar protest from Beijing.\n\nThe US delegation featuring Pelosi is reminiscent of another controversy she triggered in Asia, in 2022, when she visited Taiwan as the speaker of the US House of Representatives - despite warnings from both Beijing and the Biden administration against such a move. China responded by announcing military exercises and warned that the visit had \"a severe impact on the political foundation of China-U.S. relations.\"\n\nMeanwhile, Washington has vowed to provide the island with the means to defend itself, and has supplied Taipei with defensive weaponry. Earlier this week, the US approved the $360 million sale of more than 1,000 small armed drones to Taiwan.", "source": {"uri": "rt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "RT"}, "authors": [], "concepts":
